loans.name: Business Sisters Group

texts.en:
Bendu S. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called 'Business Sisters'. She is 30 years old, single, and has one child who is four years old.  She was only able to attend school through 12th grade. She takes care of three siblings.

For two years,she has been selling cooking oil in New Georgia, Gardnersville Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.  She sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning.  Bendu plans to use her 7,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 35,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more cooking oil.  

Her goal is to grow her business and to become an exporter in the future and to continue to support her child so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Bendu is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
El señor Pedro F. de 32 años de edad comenzó con este trabajo aproximadamente en el año 2.006. El vendió una motocicleta para poder tener un capital de trabajo, con el cual inició su propia micro empresa, compra y venta de ropas. 
En la actualidad ya tiene su clientela bien formada y estan emprendiendo un nuevo negocio(Carpinteria)y esta actividad ya forma parte de un su ingreso familiar.
El fabrica muebles de primera calidad para algunas mueblerias de la zona y otras para clientes particulares sobre pedido.
El invertiría este crédito en comprar de maderas para la fabricacion de sus muebles y el resto de crédito en la compra de más mercaderías(Ropas como: remeras, camisas, pantalones, chorps, blusas, championes y otros)
texts.en:
Pedro F. is 32 years old and started his business around the year 2006. He sold a motorcycle to be able to have capital to start his small business buying and selling clothes. Currently he has a well-established clientele and is launching a new carpentry business that will add to his family's income. He makes high-quality furniture for some furniture stores in the area and also for particular customers by request. He plans to use the loan to purchase wood to make the furniture and buy more merchandise (clothing such as shirts, pants, shorts, blouses and other items) with the rest of the money.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wood to make furniture

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a married with three children and her children go to school. She rents a two roomed house where she stays with five people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Sarah takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the famliy. She owns a restaurant in Ntinda Nsimbiziwome and sells to all categories of people on retail and also practices outside catering. She works seven days a week and receives at least 30 customers a day.  She has been in this business for 10 years and her business challenge is seasonality.  Besides this restaurant business, she also raises chickens at her home.  She has been with MCDT for some years, servicing her 10th loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more maize flour, Irish potatoes, beans, bananas, and charcoal for her restaurant. Her main customers are hawkers, vendors and passersby. She aspires to build a bigger restaurant and own a permanent house. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was giving out timely loans.

loans.use: To buy more maize flour, charcoal, irish potatoes, and bananas.

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Meriam U. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 32 years old. Meriam is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Meriam  is engaged in the retail sector, operating a buying and selling business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying agricultural crops like copra and bananas from the neighboring villages and selling them in the city. Meriam has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Meriam joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meriam has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as additional working capital. Meriam is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Meriam from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sperito

texts.en:
48-year-old, hospitable, S. Sperito has educated all his three children to university level, courtesy of his three-year-old maize-milling business in Senyi, Lugazi. He also does some poultry rearing and banana plantation farming.

Sperito became involved in this business after much persuasion from a friend who had achieved success in a similar venture. Since he began his business, he has been earning 150,000 shillings on a monthly basis.

It’s with this loan that he is seeking empowerment to financially boost his business. He wants, specifically, to buy more maize as it’s been his major selling item over these years.

loans.use: To purchase more maize to supplement his existing stock

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is  married with three children and her children go to school. She rents a two roomed house where she stays with five people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Fatuma takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. She owns a retail shop in Bukoto Mulimira Zone and sells to all categories of people on retail. She works seven days a week. Fatuma receives at least 30 customers a day and she has been in this business for ten years and her business challenge is transportation.  Besides this retail shop business, she also  and sells piped water.  She has been with MCDT for some years, servicing her sixth loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and cooking oil.  She aspires to see her business grow bigger and buy a plot of land. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and she wanted to boost her business.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of soap, cartons of salt,  boxes of soap and cooking oil

loans.name: Libertad Group

texts.es:
El Banco D. emprendimiento LIBERTAD es nuevo, esta conformado por 8 integrantes D. los cual todos los socios cuentan con negocio propio y servicios hace muchos años en la zona del mercado central del torno y otros  ambulando, la gran mayoria del banco D. emprendimiento viven en la zona D. puerto rico B/ libertad por eso el nombre del banco y todos son oriundos D. santa cruz, son personas responsables que se conocen y se garantizan entre ellos.

La presidenta del banco D. emprendimiento es la Sra. Edilia, esta casada y tiene 3 hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar, ella se dedica a la venta D. cosmeticos por catalogo y como segunda actividad a la venta D. ropa D. temporada, su esposo es chofer asalariado y el dinero que le pagan no alcanza para mantener a su familia, por eso la Sra. Edilia se dedica a estas dos actividades para colaborar con los gastos del hogar, con el dinero del c redito comprara mercaderia en cosmeticos que se encuentran en promosion para despues poder venderlos al precio original, y asi poder tener una mayor gananancia, es una persona responsable, dinamica y trabajadora solidaria con sus compañeros del banco por esta razon la nombraron presidenta dle banco.

Todas las socias son personas responsables y dinamicas que en muchos casos sacan solas a su familia adelante, estan muy agradecidas con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
The Libertad Group is a newly-formed group that has eight members, all of whom have had businesses for several years in the central market and surrounding areas. All of the members of the group are natives of Santa Cruz and the majority live in the Libertad neighborhood of the Puerto Rico district, which is how they chose the group's name. They are responsible people who know each other well and guarantee each other's repayment of the loan. Edilia is the president of the group. She is married and has three school-aged children. She sells cosmetics from catalogs and also sells clothing seasonally. Her husband is a salaried driver, but his pay does not cover their household's expenses so Edilia has her two businesses to help meet her family's needs. She will use the money from the loan to purchase cosmetics while they are on sale to later sell at full price and in that way make a better profit. She is a responsible, dynamic, and hardworking member of the group, and for this reason they named her president. All of the group's members are responsible and dynamic and are working hard to help their families get ahead. They are very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence they have shown in the group by granting it this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Lucy Jerop

texts.en:
Lucy Jerop R. is a woman of 36 who is married to Daniel R.; they are blessed with three lovely children. Lucy is a maize farmer growing crops which she later sells after harvest. She has been doing this for four years now.  She also has a secondary business where she sells milk from her dairy farming project. 

Lucy came to know about KADET through another KADET client. This will be Lucy's first loan with KADET which she plans to use to buy fertilizers worth Kshs 2,500, buy maize seedlings worth Kshs 6,000, weeding with Kshs 4,000, ploughing with Kshs 12,000 and use the balance to help in digging the farm. 

Her dream is to own a bigger plot of land and expand her business so she can earn more income to feed, clothe and shelter her family.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs like fertilizer, maize seedlings

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is  married with four children and her children go to school. She owns a three roomed house where she stays with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Mary takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. She works from her home and sells the drink by her self and sells to all categories of people both on retail and  wholesale. She works seven days a week. Mary receives at least 20 customers a day and  has been in this business for 10 years.  Business challenges include seasonality and the rainy season, which disturbs her because she works from a muddy place. Her main customers are older people and people from northern Uganda.  She has been with MCDT for many years, servicing her 14th loan. Mary wants to use this loan to buy more bags of cassava flour, maize bran and millet.  She aspires to see her business grow bigger and go directly to mills to buy millet, cassava flour and maize bran. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with low income women who want to boost their businesses.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cassava, millet and maize bran for making local brew

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina A. is from the village of Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 52 years old. Catalina is widowed and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Catalina owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling flowers in the local community. She is also engaged in selling firewood. Catalina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Catalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Catalina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as additional working capital. Catalina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Catalina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: John Gitau

texts.en:
John is a 58-year-old farmer. He is married to Anna and they have five daughters and one son who are aged between nine years and 31 years.

John was introduced to Kadet through marketing outreach and he is a dairy and horticulture farmer. He has been farming for the last four years. He plans to improve his farming with the loan he has applied for. He intends to buy a bigger pickup van to use in transportation of his farm produce with the anticipated profit.

His hopes and dreams are to build a residential house and rental houses on the piece of land he owns. 

John describes himself as a hard-working businessman.

loans.use: To improve farming

loans.name: Gilbert Kingi

texts.en:
Gilbert is a 40-year-old man, married with five children. He has been practicing farming in Kibaoni Malindi for the last two years and earns a profit of Kshs 9,700 monthly. Gilbert is also employed in a salt manufacturing company.

Gilbert was introduced to Kadet by an existing member and is applying for his first loan. He will use Kshs 3,600 of this loan for land preparation, Kshs 1,120 to buy seedlings, Kshs 3,200 to buy fertilizers and the rest will be used for weeding.  He anticipates a boost and some extra earnings from this loan which he plans to use to increase his farm acreage and pay school fees for his children. 

A hard-working man, he dreams of owning a good residential house and investing in quality education for his children.

loans.use: Buying seeds, fertilizers and paying for land preparation and weeding

loans.name: Mujeres Luchadoras Group

texts.es:
El comite Mujeres Luchadoras esta integrada por 19 Señoras muy trabajadoras quienes se unierón para trbajar en forma solidaria e independiente en donD. el compromiso es conjunto y la clave del éxito poseer un espiritu emprendedor.

Las mismas residen en el Barrio Inmaculada D. la Ciudad D. Caaguazú, actualmente estan en el 6to. Ciclo y  quieren seguir progresando. 

La señora Catalina R. es una D. las integrantes y se dedica a la cria D. pollos para vender en el mercada. Su forma D. produccion es muy peculiar ya que ella compra los pollitos y los cria en un gallinero instalado en su casa. Una vez que los pollos tienen el peso deseado por mercado ella los venD. en varios negocios.

Solicita un credito para la compra D. balanceados que son para la alimentacion D. su pollos.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Luchadoras group consists of 19 very hard-working women who came together to help their businesses. The key to their success is their enterprising spirit. The members resiD. in the Barrio Inmaculada in the city of Caaguazú, and with their sixth loan they want to keep progressing. Catalina R. is one of the members, and she makes a living raising chickens to sell at the market. Her method is unique since she purchases the chicks and then raises them in a coop set up in her home. Once the chickens reach their desired market weight she sells them to various businesses. She is requesting the loan to purchase feed for her chickens.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chicken feed

loans.name: Safina

texts.en: Safina is  married with five children and her children go to school.  Her husband is taxi driver in Kampala city.  She owns a four-roomed house where she stays with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Safina takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family.  She owns a restaurant and  a stall in Mulago selling bananas and all types of cooked food Safina sells to all categories of people  . She works seven days a week.  Safina receives at least 15 customers a day. Besides this food business, she also sells second hand clothes a stall near her restaurant . She has been in this business for many years.  She has been with MCDT for some for quite long. Safina‘s business challenges include thieves and transportation.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, cassava, meat and cooking oil and partly to buy more second hand clothes. She is aspiring of  seeing  her business grow big and  get  permanet business premise.

loans.use: Partly to buy bananas,cassava,potatoes and another part to buy second hand clothes

loans.name: Elias

texts.es: Bl Sr. ELIAS nacido el once de Diciembre de 1987, en Villa Barrientos a 5 km de Santa Rita, ahora vive en la localidad de Pacay de la Ciudad de Santa Cruz tiene su propia parcela en la cual trabaja en la agricultura sembrando distintos productos, el es soltero siembra maiz, yuca, mani, frijol y Papa. Tambien el estudia solo los dias sabado de 8:00am a 18:00pm tiene sus padres que le apoyan con su trabajo. con el dinero del credito comprara mas semillas para la siembra de Papa ya que es temporada de siembra, despues de cosecharlo lo comercializa en el mercado de la zona y asi poder incrementar su capital de trabajo, uno de sus deseos es el de terminar sus estudios y asi poder mejorar su calidad de vida, es un joven responsable y trabajador con ganas de superacion, esta muy agradecido con Emprender y Kiva por la Confianza Brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Elias, born on 11 December 1987, in Villa Barrientos, 5 kilometers from Santa Rita, now lives in Pacay neighborhood of the city of Santa Cruz. He owns his own farm plot where he grows various products like corn, manioc, peanut, bean and potato. He’s single and goes to school Saturdays from 8am to 6pm. His parents help him do his work. He will use the funds to buy potato seed because planting season is now; once harvested he will sell in the area market to increase his working capital. One of his dreams is to complete his studies in order to improve his quality of life. He’s a responsible, hard-working young man who very much wants to succeed. He is grateful to Emprender and to Kiva for the trust placed in him by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy potato seed.

loans.name: God Willing Group

texts.en:
Comfort H. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called 'God Willing'. She is 31 years old, single, and has two children who are 7 and 13 years old. She was only able to attend school through 7th grade due to lack of financial support.

For 15 years, Comfort has been selling foodstuffs such as rice and oil in the Fiamah Community in Monrovia, Liberia. She has good human relations with her customers which keeps them returning.

Comfort started by selling cola nuts but now sells on a table and hopes to improve to a better standard in the near future.  She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more rice, oil, and peppers.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Comfort is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more rice, oil and pepper

loans.name: Rusana

texts.en:
Rusana T. is from the village of Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 30 years old. Rusana is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Rusana owns & operates a business buying and selling agricultural crops like copra and banana in the local community. Rusana has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rusana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Rusana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase more bananas to sell. Rusana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Rusana from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

location.town: Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Amador Group

texts.es:
El grupo Amador está conformado por tres mujeres trabajadoras y admirables una de ellas es la señora Petrona Pérez García quien en el 2003 con la venta de una vaca y un cerdo invirtió en la compra de cosméticos, celulares, computadoras, radios entre otro productos que junto con su nieta comercializa en Costa Rica formando así un dúo dinámico. 

Su compañera Dina Ramírez desde hace siete años venta de ropa y prendas de oro y Janeth del Carmen F. R. comercializa ropa, zapatos y churros en la zona franca.
texts.en:
The Amador group consists of three hard-working and admirable women. One of the members is Petrona Pérez García, who with the money from selling a cow and a pig in 2003 invested in the purchase of cosmetics, cell phones, computers, radios and other products that she along with her granddaughter sell in Costa Rica as a dynamic duo. Fellow members Dina Ramírez has sold clothing and gold jewelry for the past seven year and Janeth del Carmen F. R. sells clothing, shoes and churros in the French zone.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics and household appliances

loans.name: Madai

texts.es:
A la vivienda de la señora Madai P. le está haciendo falta la barda alrededor de la casa. 
No cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder comprar el material y pagarle a la persona que se encargará de realizar la mejora. 
Es por eso que solicita el préstamo, ya que necesita la seguridad de su familia ya que trabaja casi todo el día y su esposo el señor Luís Reyes trabaja de noche de guardia de una compañía. 
Desean que sus dos hijos estén seguros y cómodos en su casa.
texts.en:
Madai P.'s home is missing a fence around it. She doesn't have the necessary funds to be able to purchase the materials and pay someone to make the improvements. It's for this reason she is requesting the loan, since she needs to ensure her family's security since she works practically all day and her husband, Luís Reyes, works at night as a guard for a company. They want their two children to be comfortable and secure in their home.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a fence

loans.name: Shehe Kahindi

texts.en:
Shehe K. is a 32 year old gentleman who is married to Fatuma. Together, they have four children between the ages of 18 months and 10 years. 

Shehe is a farmer at Kipini in Malindi. His clients are brokers who source goods for larger markets. The farm produce business earns him a monthly profit of KES 4,500. He also operates a grocery shop on the side. 

This is Shehe’s second loan and he has had no credit history with any other institution. With KES 7,000, this loan will help him buy seedlings, KES 8,000 wil pay for labor and KES 5,000 will be used for weeding. He plans to expand his farm acreage with the extra profit from this loan and hopes to buy his own plot of land to build rental houses.

loans.use: To buy seeds, pay for labour and weeding.

loans.name: Rojo Group

texts.es:
El grupo Rojo está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es Sandra del Socorro Jalinas Velázquez desde hace tres años vende cosméticos y ropa. Su sueño es poder llegar a tener un tramo en el mercado oriental por ello luchara arduamente.
Sus compañeras de grupo son Verónica Ninoska Hernández Martínez quien vende cosméticos y zapatos y Eugenia Martínez vende ropa y calzado. Ellas invertirán el crédito en la compra de mercadería para sus negocios.
texts.en:
The Rojo ("Red") group consists of three hard-working women. One of the members is Sandra del Socorro Jalinas Velázquez, who for the past three years has sold cosmetics and clothing. Her dream is to be able to have a post at the east market, for which she has worked for arduously. Her fellow members are Verónica Ninoska Hernández Martínez, who sells cosmetics and shoes, and Eugenia Martínez, who sells clothing and footwear. The women plan to use the loan to purchase more merchandise for their respective businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for their respective businesses

loans.name: Norah

texts.en: Norah is widowed with six children and none of her children goes to school. It's only grandchildren who go to school.  She owns a ??? roomed house where she stays with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Norah takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family.  She owns a stall in Nakawa selling yellow bananas Besieds this yellow banana business Norah also sells charcoal at the smae stall. Norah sells to all categories of people both retail and  wholesale. Norah doesn’t incur transportation charges as she buys from her place of work. She also owns rental houses.  She works seven days a week.  Norah receives at least 25 customers a day.  She has been in this business for over 20 years Norah‘s business challenges include thieves and the rainy season because she sells from an open place. She wants to use this loan  partly to buy more bunches of yellow bananas and another part to buy bags of charcoal. She aspires to see her business grow big and start going direclty to farmers. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was negotiable.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of yellow bananasand charcoal

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
El señor Mario C. de 31 años de edad, es separado, vive con él sus dos hijos, que estan cursando sus estudios primarios.
El señor Mario se dedica a la compra de rollos(maderas)y realiza algunos cortes de manera a facilitar su uso. El ademas fabricas tirantes y vigas para casas y tambien fabrica pisos parquet para algunos clientes. 
En su aserradero posee todas las herramientas para trabajar con maderas. 
   Don Mario se inició en este rubro desde muy pequeño aproximadamente en el año 1.998; ya que el aserradero donde el esta como encargado perteneció a su padre, en la actualidad el le provee de pisos a dos empresas parqueteras importantes de la ciudad, hace ya unos años.
   El invertiría este crédito en comprar más rollos teniendo en cuenta el compromiso que tiene con esas dos empresas.
texts.en:
Mario C. is 31 years old, separated, and lives with his two children both who are in elementary school. His business is buying timber and cutting it down into usable pieces. Additionally he makes braces and beams for houses and constructs hardwood floor for some clients. At his sawmill he has all of the tools need to work with wood.

Mario has been doing this type of work since he was young, since approximately 1998. Back the the sawmill where he works was run by his father. Nowadays they provide floors for two important companies in the city. He will use this loan to buy more wood to fulfill his commitment to the two companies.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy timber to process

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing of palm trees for the production of palm wine [for resale]

loans.name: El Malinche Group

texts.es:
El grupo El Malinche I lo conforman tres mujeres trabajadoras, decididas y emprendedoras un ejemplo de ello es la señora Aura Lila B. Simones  quien desde hace cuatro años se dedica a realizar enchiladas y sopas los fines de semana ya sea de mondongo, de albóndiga, hueso, de res, de queso y de marisco.
Sus compañeros de grupo son Julia Pérez vende gaseosa pollo, helados  y cría animales domésticos  como gallina y cerdos mientras Maricela G. tiene una pequeña miscelánea. Ellos invertirán el crédito en productos para sus negocios.
texts.en:
The El Malinche I group is made up of three hard-working, purposeful, enterprising women. An example is Aura Lila B. Simones who has made mondongo (tripe), meatball, beef bone, cheese and seafood enchiladas and soups on weekends for the last four years. Her fellow group members are Julia Pérez, who sells soft-drinks, chicken and frozen treats and also raises small farm animals like chickens and pigs, and Maricela Gonzalez who has a small general store. They will invest the funds in products for their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For basic grains, vegetables, meat, soup bones, etc.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena Y. sells vegetables such as okra, garden eggs (small whitish eggplants), tomatoes, and others at Abura. Abena has been through junior high school. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a driver. 

Abena has been selling vegetables for some time now. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy additional vegetables for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to educate her children.

loans.use: buy additional vegetables for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy hair extensions

loans.name: Efigenia

texts.es:
La señora Efigenia Baez de 59 años está acompañado hace 30 años con el señor Claudelino Benítez de 55 años de edad, la pareja cuenta con cinco hijos  todos mayores de edad de los cuales dos trabaja en el exterior, uno  vive en forma independiente  y los otros dos viven con sus padres ayudando en el trabajo diario y actualmente nadie mas estudia en la casa. 

La Sra. Efigenia está en este negocio hace 26 años, realiza Confecciones de ropas sobre pedido, su esposo cuenta con su propia carpintería, juntos tienen buen ingreso mensual siempre ayudado por los hijos y con eso mejorar cada dia el nivel de la familia e ir mejorando la infraestructura de la casa.

Solicita este préstamos para compra de telas y maderas que cada uno utilizará en su negocio y asi ofrecer a sus clientes buenos articulos.
texts.en:
Sra. Efigenia Baez is 59 years old and has been married 30 years to Sr. Claudelino Benítez, who is 55. The couple has five adult children: two of them work abroad, one lives independently, and the other two still live with them and help with the daily work. No one in the household is currently attending school.

Sra. Efigenia has been making clothes by order for 26 years. Her husband has his own carpentry shop. Together they generate a good monthly income. Their children always help them, thereby improving both the standard of living for their family and the infrastructure of their house.

Sra. Efigenia is requesting a loan to buy fabric for her sewing business and wood for her husband’s carpentry shop so that they can offer their customers good products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric for her sewing business & wood for her husband's carpentry shop

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en:
M. Ronald appears on the left in the photo; the person on the right is a credit officer.

Ronald is the 44-year-old married father of five children. All his children are in school, though he subsists on a lowly source of income which is selling phone accessories. He has been doing this business for the last eleven years in Nazigo, Kayunga.

With this experience, Ronald has managed to weather the financial storms that have afflicted his business over this period of time. In a month, he reveals he makes profits amounting to 90,000 shillings.

Ronald’s future plan is to go wholesale. He wants the assistance of this loan to help him buy new phone accessories like batteries and chargers.

loans.use: To buy more phone accessories like batteries and chargers

loans.name: Señor  De Malta Group

texts.es:
El Banco D. Emprendimiento "SR. D. MALTA " es un grupo  que se encuentra en su cuarto  ciclo, esta conformado por 11 miembros 9 mujeres y 2 varones, todos se conocen y se garantizan entre ellos, este grupo esta representada por las siguientes socias: 

La Presidenta es la Sra. Betty  quien es la lider y fundadora del banco, tiene el negocio D. venta D. hamburguesas, en la Av. Zuecia zona Huayra kàsa, est zona es una D. las zonas populosas D. la ciudad D. cochabamba, Esta casada  y tiene 5 hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar, su esposo es chofer asalariado y el dinero que le pagan no alcanza para el sustento D. su familia, por esta razon la señora Betty le ayuda con los gastos del hogar para asi poder sacar a su numerosa familia adelante, con el dinero del credito comprara insumos e ingredientes al por mayor para la elaboracion D. sus hamburguesas.

Como Secretaria esta la Sra. Maria quien es casada y tiene 2 hijas pequeñas   es una persona muy responsable y puntual con sus cuotas venD. comida en la zona temporal, es una persona  activa y amable con sus compañeras con el dinero del credito comprara insumos e ingredientes para la elaboracion D. sus comidas.

Todas las socias son personas responsables y dinamicas que en muchos casos sacan a su familia adelante solas, estan muy agradecidas con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
The enterprising bank "SR. D. MALTA " is in its forth cycle. The group is maD. up of eleven women and two men who all know and support each other. This group is represented by the following members: Mrs. Betty is the president. She is the leader and founder of the bank. She has a business selling hamburgers on Suecia Avenue in the Huayra kàsa neighborhood. This is one of the most populated areas of the city, Cochabamba. She is married and has five school-age children. Her husband is a salaried driver but the money he is paid is not enough to take care of his family. This is why Mrs. Betty helps him with the household bills so they can get their large family ahead. They will buy wholesale supplies and ingredients to make hamburgers with the loan money. Mrs. Maria is the group's secretary. She is married and has two small children. She is a person who is very responsible and punctual with her payments. She sells food in a temporary area and is active and nice to her companions. She will buy supplies and ingredients to make food with the loan money. All the members are responsible and dynamic people who, in many cases, get their family's ahead on their own. They are very grateful for Emprender and Kiva for trusting them with a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase of Working Capital

loans.name: Los Galanes Group

texts.es:
El grupo los Galanes está conformado por Ena del Carmen R. L., Raquel Nohemi Torres Gaitán  y Luis Beltrán R. Méndez  tres personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que se dedican al comercio de frutas y verduras.

Este grupo ha sido participe tanto de los beneficios financieros como del proceso de capacitación y formación sobre genero y desarrollo empresarial que le ha ayudado a ayudado a administrar sus negocios eficazmente. Un claro ejemplo de ello es la señora Ena del Carmen R. L., coordinadora del grupo, quien en el 2003 inicio a vender perecederos en el mercado especialmente mangos, tamarindo y  mamón.

 Ella en un comienzo comercializaba pocos productos ya que no contaba con dinero suficiente para invertir más. Actualmente R. compra mayor cantidad y variedad de cosechas con lo que su negocio ha progresado satisfactoriamente y sueña en tener un futuro no muy lejano otro tramo en el cual comercializara ropa usada.
texts.en:
Ena del Carmen R. L., Raquel Nohemi Torres Gaitá and Luis Beltrán R. Méndez are the members of the Los Galanes group. They are three hard-working, enterprising people that are fruit and vegetable merchants. This group has participated in financial benefits, training sessions, gender and business development workshops that have helped them better manage their businesses. A clear example of this is Ena del Carmen R. L., group coordinator, who started selling perishables like mangos, tamarind and mammon (a tropical Central American fruit) in 2003. At the beginning, she only sold a few products because she lacked sufficient funds to stock more. Currently, she buys a wider variety of crops in larger amounts so that her business has progressed satisfactorily and she dreams of having a space to sell second-hand clothes in the not too distant future.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruit crops and seasonal vegetables.

loans.name: Lanaya Group

texts.fr:
Les sept  femmes du groupe LANAYA (6 femmes mariées  et une célibataire) ont  une moyenne d’âge de 46ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.0
Ce groupe de femmes mènent diverses activités telle la vents des produits cosmétiques, de fruits, de condiments alimentaires et de chaussures avec Sokona Keïta.
Sokona K.  compte acheter avec son  prêt,  55 paires de chaussures.
Elle s’approvisionne à BOBO pays voisin du Mali  et dans le grand marché de Sikasso. Les chaussures sont vendues la plupart au comptant, au  marché du quartier Sanoubougou I et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne pour des fins sociaux et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The seven women in the LANAYA group (six married women and one unmarried) are on average 46 years old with two children, living in monogamous families in SANOUBOUGOU I, one of the boroughs of Sikasso, in the 3rd administrative region of Mali. This is the first time they collaborate with the Soro Yorowaso MFI to satisfy their customers’ needs. This group of women carry out several activities, among which the sale of beauty products, fruit, food condiments, and shoes (like Sokona Keïta). Sokona Keïta will use her loan to buy 55 pairs of shoes. She gets her supplies from Bobo (in neighbouring Burkina Faso), and from the main market in Sikasso. The shoes are sold mainly for cash by family members at the Sanoubougou I borough market, to both men and women customers. She expects to achieve average monthly earnings of 15,000 FCFA of which part will be put into savings for social use and the remainder invested in her commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes

loans.name: Sanayelen Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe SANAYELEN,  sont 7 femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles polygames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’habits, de céréales, de condiments et des fruits avec Assa D.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt,  5 chargements de charrette de fruits .
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché, dans les vergers de  Sikasso et les villages voisins . Les fruits sont vendus au  marché du quartier Sanoubougou I et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans l’éducation et la santé des enfants et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the SANALEYEN group are seven married women who average 36 years of age and have an average of four children. They live in polygamous families in SANOUBOUGOU 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are taking out their first loan from the microfinance institution, Soro, Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy the needs of their customers. This group of women trade in clothes, cereals, condiments and, in the case of Assa D., fruits. The latter is planning to buy five barrowloads of fruits with her loan. She gets her supplies at the large market, in Sikasso's orchards and the neighboring villages. The fruits are sold at the market in the district of Sanoubougou 1 and within the family, to a customer base made up of men and women. She envisages making an average monthly profit of 12,000FCFA of which part will be used to help her husband pay for the children's education and health and the rest to invest in her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits

loans.name: El Buen Pastor Group

texts.es:
El grupo Buen Pastor está integrado por tres personas trabajadoras que en el tiempo que tienen de trabajar con Adim se han desarrollado tanto como microempresarias que son como en sus conocimiento según mencionaron. Esto es debido a que ahora cuentan con una mejor comunicación, administración y otros conocimientos que le ayudan en su trabajo y hogar.
 Una de ella es la señora María Felix M. quien en 1990 inicio a comercializar unas cuantas frutas y verduras en el Mercado de Masaya. En este tiempo y con su esfuerzo y el de sus hijos de 18 y 13 años, quienes le ayudan en el negocio, ha mejorado considerablemente según comento ahora trabaja con mayor inversión, más desahogada y puede adquirir cosechas más grandes.
Sus compañeras de grupo son Sabina P. desde hace 25 años vende frutas y tamales (comida típica nicaragüense a base de maíz nesquisado y se envuelve en hojas de chaquite) y Ana María Ruiz vende cosméticos de la marca Avon y Ropa.
texts.en:
The Buen Pastor (Good Shepherd) group is made up of three hard-working people who have developed as micro entrepreneurs and in their general knowledge while associated with Adim because they have improved communication, management and other skills that help them both at work and at home. One of them is María Felix M. who started out in 1990 selling a few fruits and vegetables in Masaya’s market. Now, through her own efforts and with help from her 18- and 13-year-old sons who help her with the business, she has improved considerably; she now has a larger investment, she is less strapped and can acquire larger crops. Her fellow group members are: Sabina P. who has sold fruit and tamales (typical Nicaraguan dish made from hulled cornmeal wrapped in banana leaves) for the last 25 years and Ana María Ruiz who sells Avon products and clothes.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seasonal crops.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama O. is married to a driver and lives with her six dependents. She has received junior high education. Ama fries and smokes fish for sale at Abura. (She goes to buy the fish fresh, comes home to clean them, and fries them for sale.)  

Ama uses her income she generates from her sales to help her husband in providing the basic needs of their dependents. Ama will add the loan to her original capital to purchase more fish to process (smoke) and then sell. With the new earnings from her expanded business, Ama plans to reinvest into her business.

loans.use: add the loan to her original capital to purchase more fish

loans.name: Zula

texts.en: Zula is a single mother of three children and her children go to school ??? working . She owns a ??? roomed house where she stays with six people. The family has no access to electricity but has piped water. Zula takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family and medication. Zula owns a store where she sells charcoal. Zula receives at least 15 customers a day and her customers are mainly her neighbors.  Zula has been in this business for some years and her business challenges include thieves and transportation. Besides this charcoal business, she also gets some money from rental houses. Zula has been with MCDT for some years, servicing her fifth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal and ????

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Espíritu Santo Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Paraguari, Km. 56 , se reunieron unas señoras con la idea de  aumentar su capital de trabajo y para emprender actividades productivas, de ahí que coordinaron la reunión para interiorizarse sobre el programa, a quienes les agradó bastante pues era una buena oportunidad crediticia y trabajarían en grupo.
El comité lleva por nombre Espíritu Santo, actualmente se encuentran en el tercer ciclo integrada por 19  luchadoras mujeres, quienes se sacrifican días tras días para aumentar sus ingresos y por ende brindarle lo mejor a sus respectivas familias.
 La señora Alicia Paéz es una de las integrantes y solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercaderías(arroz, fideos, harina, panificados, embutidos.) ya que ella posee un almacén con todos los artículos de primera necesidad y lo vende a precios bien accesibles para sus clientes.
Ella comenta que el negocio es primordial para la familia ya con los ingresos que obtienen de el cubre todo los gastos de alimentación de la familia y podemos llevar  una buena calidad de vida.
texts.en:
A group of women got together in the city of Paraguari, kilometer 56 marker, with the idea of increasing their working capital in order to engage in productive activities. This led to their learning about the program in detail which they liked very much because it offered a good credit opportunity and they could work as a group. The committee is called Espíritu Santo (Holy Spirit) and it’s currently in its 3rd loan cycle; it has 19 hard working women as members who make sacrifices day after day in order to increase their earnings and thus provide their families with all the best. Alicia Paéz is one of the group members and she is asking for funds to buy merchandise like: rice, pasta, flour, baked and canned goods because she has a grocery store stocked with basic need items that she sells to her customers at reasonable prices. She states that the business is vital for her family because the profits earned provide for the family’s daily nutrition thereby providing a good quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic need items, cleaning supplies, canned goods.

loans.name: Gnogodeme Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf femmes du groupe Gnogondeme sont toutes mariées, avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames  à Siekourani un village de la sous préfecture de LOULOUNI   région de Sikasso 3 e région du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur troisième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’accroitre leur chiffre d’affaire. 
Ce groupe de femme exerce le commerce de pagnes, de condiments alimentaires et de céréales telle le riz   avec Mawa O. 
Mawa O. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  3 sacs de 50 kg de riz . Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Loulouni et dans les foires des villages voisins. 
Le riz est revendu en détail au marché de Loulouni à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 7 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne pour des fins sociaux et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The nine women of the Gnogondeme group are all married, average 39 years of age and have an average of four children. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Siekourani, a village in the sub-prefecture of LOULOUNI, in the region of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are taking out their third loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of increasing their turnover. This group of women trade in "pagnes" (colourful West African fabric), condiments and, in the case of Mawa O., cereals such as rice. Mawa O. is planning to buy three 50kg bags of rice with her loan. She gets her supplies at the market in Loulouni and in fairs in neighboring villages. The rice is resold on a retail basis at the market in Loulouni, to a customer base made of men and women, for cash. She envisages making an average monthly profit of 7,000FCFA, of which part will be saved for social purposes and the rest invested in her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice

loans.name: María Eugenia

texts.es:
La señora  María Eugenia F. es socia del banco  Vegaspamba ubicado en la parroquia Jadán  aquí su gente se dedica a la agricultura y cría de animales de corral como pollos y cerdos, su gente es muy amable y tienen la costumbre de brindar  la tradicional chicha de jora sobre todo durante sus festividades así como también el fiambre(comida), para las mingas, trabajos voluntarios y solidarios de la comunidad se convoca mediante la quipa (caracol del mar) también se puede  observar que la gente mantiene su vestimenta tradicional de lana, sombrero, lliglla (chalina), pantalones y polleras.

Nuestra socia tiene 38 años, de estado civil casada y fruto de su unión conyugal concibió  cuatro  hijos de 16, 14, 12, 9 años, su primer hijo trabaja como latonero, el dinero de su trabajo es para sus gastos  personales y para sus estudios en un colegio a distancia, su segundo hijo le ayuda en los quehaceres del  hogar y  sus dos últimos hijos estudian en la escuela de la comunidad, su esposo trabaja en la construcción, la casa que posee es pequeña  hecha de tablas.

 María Eugenia elabora  sogas de cabuya   desde  muy corta edad, éste arte aprendió de su madre y ahora se ha convertido en  un método de vida, trabaja en sus tiempos libres ya que también debe atender los quehaceres de su hogar y cuidar de sus hijos más pequeños, se encuentra muy contenta de estar con un grupo de mujeres que siempre buscan la mejor manera de salir adelante con sus familias,  este es  su octavo ciclo y con el dinero de su crédito comprará artículos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, aceite, sal, artículos de limpieza y cuidado personal, entre otros víveres, así como también para cubrir algunos gastos escolares de sus hijos y, una parte para adquirir cabuya para elaborar las sogas.

Su sueño es llegar a tener una casa de losa.
texts.en:
María Eugenia F. is a member of the Vegaspamba community bank in the parish of Jadán, where the people make a living in agriculture and raise farm animals such as chickens and pigs. The people are very friendly and have the custom of toasting with traditional maize liquor during festivals where they also maintain their traditional dress with wool garments and sombreros. María is 38 years old, married and has four children, ages 16, 14, 12 and 9. Her first son works at a body shop, and the money he makes he uses for personal expenses and for his education at a distant school. Her second son helps with household chores, and her two youngest children go to a community school. Her husband works in construction. They live in a small home made of planks. María has made ropes since she was very young. She learned the craft from her mother and it has now become a way of life. She works in her free time since she has to tend to the household chores and care for her youngest children. She is very content to belong to a community bank with women who are always looking for a better way to make headway for their families. This is her eighth loan, and with the money she plans to purchase primary-need items such as rice, sugar, oil, salt, cleaning and personal products, among other provisions. She will also use it to cover some of the costs of her children's education, and another part to acquire supplies to make her ropes. Her dream is to have a house made of stone.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase provisions, pay for children's education and buy supplies to make ropes

loans.name: El Ceibo Group

texts.es:
En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer Panamericana, se reúne la Asociación Comunal EL CEIBO, con 9 integrantes éste será su crédito número  15, por lo tanto, están juntos hace 7 años aproximadamente.
Una de las antiguas integrantes es Felicidad C., que con el valor y amor de madre logró sacar adelante a sus 8 hijos, ella ha sido padre y madre para ellos.
Felicidad vende comida, con sus habilosas manos prepara ricos platos como chicharrón de pollo, silpancho, thimpu y otros. Ella se siente un poco cansada y desea iniciar un nuevo negocio, específicamente dedicarse a la compra y venta de papel higiénico, traerlo de Desaguadero y venderlo en Cochabamba, para lo cual necesita el préstamo y si le fuera mal ella volvería a su antiguo negocio.
 
Todas necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería, insumos o materia prima, según el negocio que tengan.
texts.en:
The nine members of the EL CEIBO Community Group meet at a regional office for Kiva partner Pro Mujer Panamericana. This will be the group's 15th loan, accordingly, the members have been together for about seven years. One of the oldest members is Felicidad C., who with the courage and love of her mother was able to make headway for her eight children, to whom she has been both a father and mother. Felicidad sells food. With her talented hands she prepares tasty meals such as fried chicken and other popular regional dishes. She is feeling a little tired and wishes to start up a new business, specifically one dedicated to buying and selling toilet paper, bringing it from the city of Desaguadero and selling it in the city of Cochabamba. To do this, she needs a loan, and if things go badly she will return to her former business. All the member need the loan to acquire more merchandise, ingredients or raw materials for their respective businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Acquire more merchandise, ingredients or raw materials for their respective businesses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying hairdressing supplies

loans.name: Hakilitoyerela. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe Hakilitoyerela sont toutes mariées,  avec une moyenne d’âge de 39ans, 4 enfants et  vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Siekourani un village de la  sous préfecture de Loulouni  région de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur quinzième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Ce groupe de femme fait le commerce de condiments alimentaires, de fruits et légumes, de bois de chauffe et de céréales  telle la vente de riz  avec Mariam B. D..
Mariam B. D. compte acheter avec son  prêt, 15 sacs de 100 kg de riz. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Loulouni et dans les foires des villages voisins. 
Le riz est  revendu en détail au marché de Loulouni à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 16.750FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne pour des fins sociaux et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four members of the Hakilitoyerela group are of an average age of 39, are married and have four children; they generally live in polygamous families in Siekourani which is in the sub-prefecture of the Loulouni region of Sikasso, the third largest region of Mali. They are on their fifteenth collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation, so that they can meet their customers' demands. This group of women sell food condiments alongside fruit, vegetables, firewood and cereals such as rice - all with the help of Mariam B. D.. Mariam D. aims to use her loan to buy 15 10 kg bags of rice. She sources her goods from Loulouni and the neighbouring villages. The rice is sold for cash at the Loulouni market to a customer base made up of men and women. She envisages generating an average monthly profit of 16,750 FCFA; some of this will be saved for social ends and the other part will be reinvested in business activities.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice

loans.name: Monte Verde Group

texts.es:
El grupo Monte Verde está integrado por tres personas trabajadoras, una de ellas es Juana Mercedes M. N. de 23 años es una joven esforzada y con iniciativa ella tiene una pequeña pulpería en su casa de habitación en la cual su mamá atiende mientras ella vende en el mercado frutas como jocotes.
Sus compañeros de grupo son José Augusto Pichardo y Liseth Marvelly L. los cuales comercializan frutas y verduras de acuerdo a la temporada.
texts.en:
The Monte Verde ("Green Mountain") group consists of three hard-working people. One of the members is Juana Mercedes M. N., a 23-year-old young woman who thanks to initiative has a small convenience store out of her home. Her mother tends to the store while she sells fruits such as plums at the market. Her fellow members are José Augusto Pichardo and Liseth Marvelly L., who sell fruits and vegetables in accordance to the season.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase basic grains, meats and other products

loans.name: 16 De Julio Group

texts.es:
El Banco comunal 16 D. JULIO  en su Secuencia 3, está formado por 9 clientes, todas mujeres , todas  las socias son vecinas D. la Zona D. Kupini, las socias se dedican a la venta D. diversos productos como ser, D. ropa, comida, venta D. verduras, y la confección y venta D. delantales, condimentos   y una D. las socias trabaja con el hermano en cerrajería . En la secuencia anterior todas cancelaron  aunque tuvieron retrasos por problemas que atravesaron D. forma personal  pero terminaron D. cancelar hasta el ultimo pago.

La Sra. Carmen Rosa es presidenta del banco se dedica venta D. comida en lugares concurridos o lugares donD. se realice algún acontecimiento en las diferentes zonas , cuenta con esta actividad hace 5 años, La señora vive con su esposo hace 40 años  aproximadamente, vive con sus  dos  nietos,  ya por diferentes circunstancias los nietos se quedaron bajo su cargo, la señora Carmen ayuda a su marido para  la mantención D. toda su familia, siendo que cuenta con pocos recursos económicos, los créditos obtenidos D. la institución, le apoyaron para salir adelante junto a su familia y a sus hijos el préstamo será destinado para acceder comprar llantas para el taxi que se hace cargo el esposo y lo que reste para aumentar el capital para su negocio. En el banco comunal se ha destacado como una persona responsable y puntual en sus pagos y muy alegre.

La Sra. Guadalupe es socia antigua vive en la zona D. kupini   no esta casada vive con sus hijos , asume el rol D. padre y madre para sus hijos siendo que ellos están  en una etapa D. crecimiento necesita mas recursos económicos para su alimentación y sus vestimenta razón  por la que la señora tiene que trabajar, ella al igual que su familia viven en una casa ocupando dos cuartos es una familia D. bajos recursos económicos el crédito solicitado es para la compra D. tela para la elaboración D. delantales y en adelante poder conformar un pequeña microempresa D. costura, Es una D. las representantes en su banco comunal, que ha sido elegida por su  responsabilidad y el compañerismo que ha demostrado en su proceso D. capacitación.

La Sra. Alicia es socia antigua en La Banca comunal  es reelegida como secretaria D. actas por las cualidades que tiene, ella trabaja junto a su hermano  en cerrajería  comparten el negocio D. manera que el crédito esta destinado al aumento D. capital en dicho negocio. Su esposo trabaja como empleado en una empresa y para ayudar en los gastos D. la familia la señora decidió trabajar con el hermano desD. hace 3 años adquiriendo ella experiencia en dicho negocio. Su familia esta conformada por su esposos y sus tres hijos. Su meta es tener su propio negocio D. cerrajería y así poder independizase para lograr secar a sus hijos profesionales, con el dinero del credito comprara arco para soldar.

Todas las socias estan agradecidas con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion dle credito.
texts.en:
The 16 D. Julio Communal Bank, in its third loan cycle, is maD. up of nine members, all women. They are neighbors in the Kupini zone of La Paz. The members have diverse businesses, such as sales of clothing, food, produce, and condiments; the making and sale of aprons; and one member works with her brother in a locksmith shop. In their previous loan cycle, all members maD. their payments, even if personal problems caused a delay. At the end, they completed all their payments. Carmen Rosa, the president of the communal bank, works selling food in busy locations or at events around town. She has had this business for five years. Carmen lives with her husband of 40 years and their two grandchildren, who are in their care. Carmen helps her husband with the maintenance of the family, as they are of low economic resources. The loans from Emprender have helped them and their family to get ahead. This loan will be used to buy tires for her husband’s taxi, and for working capital for her business. In the communal bank, Carmen stands out as a responsible, cheerful person, always punctual in her payments. Guadalupe is a long-time member who lives in the Kupini zone. She is not married and lives with her children. She assumes the roles of both mother and father for her children, who at this stage of life need more resources for food and clothing. They are a low-income family and the all live in two rooms. Guadalupe will use this loan to buy cloth for making aprons and continue building her small sewing business. She is one of the representatives of the communal bank, and has been chosen for the responsibility and team spirit she has demonstrated. Alicia is also a long-time member of the communal bank. She has been re-elected as recording secretary for the qualities she possesses. Alicia works with her brother in a locksmith shop. She began working with her brother three years ago, gaining experience in this business. She is married and has three children. Her goal is to have her own locksmith business to be independent and help her children become well educated. With the money from this loan, she will buy an arc welder. All the members are grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence represented by this loan.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Esther

texts.es: Esther tiene 20 años, actualmente convive con su pareja y fruto de ello, tienen una hija. Juntos viven en su casa propia, ubicada en la selva cuzqueña. Esther, una joven soñadora y trabajadora, recuerda que antes de tener su tienda, ofrecía sus productos tocando puertas, sin tener que estar esperando algún cliente que la busque, de esa manera sus ventas crecían al igual que sus ingresos. Con el tiempo obtuvo una lista de clientes fijos, eso le dio ventaja para instalar su tienda, ofreciendo a todo el público en general, variados productos a precios competitivos. Usualmente trabaja con su pareja, pero en ocasiones recibe la ayuda  de sus padres y su horario de trabajo empieza desde las 5:00 AM hasta las 9:00PM. En lo sucesivo desea ampliar su tienda con la finalidad de seguir satisfaciendo a sus clientes. Este es su cuarto crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a cumplir con su obligaciones de pago, además agradece a su grupo comunal por el apoyo que le brindan. Con el crédito que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de productos, con el propósito de surtir su tienda.
texts.en:
Esther, 20, lives with her partner and their daughter in their own home located in the Cusco jungle. Esther, a hard-working, hopeful young woman, remembers how she used to sell door-to-door before she had her store; she didn’t wait for customers to find her. Her sales grew as well as her income. In time, she secured a base of repeat customers that gave her the edge she needed to open her own store; she stocks an assortment of products that she sells for reasonable prices to the general public. She usually works with her partner and sometimes her parents help her. She is open for business from 5am until 9pm. In the future, she would like to expand her store to continue to satisfy customer demand. This is her 4th loan with MFP and she pledges to repay in a timely fashion. She is also grateful to her communal group for the support they give her. She will use the requested funds to buy stock items for her store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les huit  femmes du groupe JIGUISSEME sont toutes mariées,  avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et  3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames  à Siekourani un village de la sous préfecture de LOULOUNI   région de Sikasso 3 e région du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’agrandir leurs activités. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers, condiments, charbon de bois et  de céréales telle le riz   avec Machitan B..
Machitan B. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  4sacs de 50 kg de riz . Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Loulouni et dans les foires des villages voisins. 
Le riz est revendu en détail au marché de Loulouni à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 6 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne pour des fins sociaux et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités commerciales.
texts.en:
The eight women in the Jiguisseme group are all of an average age of 40, and are married with three children each. They mostly live in polygamous families in Siekourani, a village in the sub-prefecture of Loulouni, in Sikasso, the third largest administrative region of Mali. They are on their first collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation, with the aim of boosting their business activities. The women sell various items, such as condiments, firewood and cereals, such as rice, with Machitan B.. Machitan B. aims to use this loan to buy four 50kg bags of rice. She sources this from the Loulouni market and in the neighbouring village markets. The rice is sold for cash at the Loulouni market to a customer base made up of men and women. She envisages enerating an average monthly profit of 6,000 FCFA - a small proportion of this will be used to save for social ends and the rest re-invested in business activities.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For purchasing rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying rice

loans.name: José Manuel

texts.es:
El señor José Manuel C. C., tienen 43 años y con su esposa y sus 3 hijos habitan en el Barrio La concepción, sus dos hijos menores  actualmente estudian la escuela secundaria, el mayor se ayuda trabajando como jardinero para el transporte, comida y fotocopias de su universidad,  ellos son agricultores desde hace 21 años, y así mismo tienen un taller de ebanistería que gracias a su padre que le dejo de herencia les ha ayudado a conseguir el sustento diario del hogar, pero su fente de ingresos mayor es el cultivo de la piña.

Sus días en la agricultura comenzaron gracias a la enseñanzas que sus padres le brindaron en este rubro, dentro de los problemas básicos que se han enfrentado ha sido la falta de apoyo de los secotres prestatarios pero ha encontrado un apoyo en Afodenic gracias a los fondos Kiva, él solicita este préstamo, para la compra de materiales agrícolas, insumos vegetativos, y fertilizantes, que aporten un mejor mantenimiento a las tierras, para que la cosecha se reproduzca de buena manera y que su posterior venta aporte a las finanzas del hogar, ya sea en la inversión de futuros proyectos del negocio o personales.
texts.en:
José Manuel C. C., 43, lives with his wife and three children in the La Concepción neighborhood; their two youngest children are in secondary school and their oldest works as a gardener to pay for some of his university expenses like, transportation, food and photocopies. They have been farmers for the last 21 years and also have a cabinet-making workshop that he inherited from his father that helps him earn income for the daily support of his home. However, his main source of income comes from pineapple farming. His farming days began thanks to skills his parents imparted to him. Among the basic problems he faces is the lack of support from traditional credit institutions. However, he has gotten help from Afodenic thanks to Kiva funds. He is asking for this loan for land management so that his crops will be good and subsequent crop sales will provide income for his household either for future investments or for personal expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Santa Amalia Group

texts.es:
El grupo Santa Amalia lo conforman Cruz V. P., Damaris L. Torres y Grethel del Carmen P. tres mujeres trabajadoras, emprendedoras y esforzadas. La coordinadora del grupo es la señora V. P. quien hace cinco años con  quinientos córdobas comenzó su negocio de venta de frutas y verduras. Ella con el préstamo comprara productos como sandilla, jocote y melón.
Sus compañeras de grupo son Damaris L. Torres y Grethel del Carmen P. quienes se dedican al comercio de frutas y verduras de acuerdo a la temporada.
texts.en:
The Santa Amalia group’s members are: Cruz V. P., Damaris L. Torres and Grethel del Carmen P., three hard-working, enterprising and tenacious women. The group coordinator is Mrs. V. P. who started her fruit and vegetable selling business five years ago with 500 córdobas. She will use the requested funds to buy fruit like: watermelon, melon and jocote (a tropical fruit). Her fellow group members are: Damaris L. Torres and Grethel del Carmen P. who sell seasonal fruits and vegetables.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruit crops.

loans.name: Jiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe JIGUIYA sont toutes mariées. Elles  avec une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et ont en moyenne 5 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames   à  Siekourani un village de la  sous préfecture de Loulouni  région de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont à leur quinzième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’accroitre leur chiffre d’affaire.  
Ce groupe de femme mène la vente de tomates fraîches, de poissons fumés, de bois de chauffe et de tubercules tels avec Assa Bagayoko.
Assa B. compte acheter avec son  prêt, 50  chargements de charrettes en  ignames. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Loulouni et dans les foires des villages voisins. 
L’igname est  revendu en détail au marché de Loulouni à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne pour des fins sociaux et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women in the Jiguiya group are all married with five children each and an average age of 42. They mainly live in polygamous families in Siekourani, a village in the sub-prefecture of Loulouni, Sikasso - the third largest administrative region of Mali. They are on their fifteenth collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso region, with the aim of boosting their business revenues. The group members, such as Assa Bagayoko, sell fresh tomatoes, smoked fish, firewood and tubers. She aims to use her loan to buy 50 cartloads of yams, sourcing her goods from the Loulouni market and from the neighbouring villages. The yams are sold for cash at the Loulouni market to a male and female customer base. She expects to generate an average monthly profit of 15,000 FCFA; a proportion of this will be used to save towards social ends and the rest will be re-invested in the business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing yams

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is married with six children and her children go to school. She owns a four roomed house where she stays with nine people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Rose takes care of additional family members. Her husband works in Nakawa Marketas a food vendor.  The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family and medication. Rose owns a store where she sells charcoal and receives at least 20 customers a day. Her customers are mainly her neighbors.  Besides this charcoal business, she also sells firewood and millet. Rose has been in this business for some years and her business challenges include seasonality and transportation. Rose has been with MCDT for six years, servicing her 24th loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal, firewood and millet. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a delivery van.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal, firewood and millet

loans.name: Vecindad De Alto Lima Group

texts.es:
Nelly M. integrante de la Asociación Comunal Vecindad de Alto Lima que a su vez pertenece al Centro Focal Alto Lima, tiene 44 años y es vecina de la ciudad de El Alto, indica que ingresó a Pro Mujer a invitación de su hermana y porque realmente necesita el dinero. 
Ella vende comida hace dos años, este negocio fue transferido por su hermana, con el crédito tiene planificado comprar víveres al por mayor como la papa, el fideo y arroz, adquiere su insumos de la ciudad de La Paz, zona El Tejar, como el negocio tiene mucho movimiento cuenta con la ayuda de sus sobrinas.

Las demás integrantes de esta  Asociación tienen actividades económicas como: atención de tienda, cerrajería,  servicio de amplificación, venta de ropa, joyería, venta de repuestos de máquina.
 
Todas necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería, insumos o materia prima, según el negocio que tengan.
texts.en:
Nelly M. is a member of the Communal Association “Vecindad de Alto Lima” (Neighborhood of Alto Lima), which is part of the Alto Lima Community Center. She is 44 years old and a resident of the city of El Alto. Nelly says she joined Pro Mujer because her sister invited her and she needed the money. She has been selling food for two years and took over the business from her sister. Her loan will be used to buy groceries in bulk such as potatoes, noodles, and rice. She obtains her supplies in the city of La Paz, El Tejar District. Her business generates a lot of traffic, so she has the help of her nieces.

The other members of the Association engage in business activities such as managing grocery stores, providing locksmith services, renting out sound equipment, selling clothing, selling jewelry, and selling machine parts. They all need a loan to acquire merchandise supplies, and raw materials according to their respective businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase groceries for preparing meals

loans.name: Enrique Avenamar

texts.es:
El señor Enrique Avenamar E. está agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual ye ayudo a que se negocio tuviera mas inventario. 
Está nuevamente solicitando un préstamo para poder comprar mercancía y material para la venta de helados ya que tiene la propuesta de distribuir su producto por varios centro comerciales de la ciudad. 
No cuenta con el dinero necesario para esta inversión es por eso que está solicitando su cooperación para esté otro crédito, y así invertir en el negocio para que tengo mas ingreso. Y con el cual planea pagar el préstamo.
texts.en:
Sr. Enrique Avenamar E. is grateful for the assistance of his previous loan, which helped him acquire more inventory for his business.

He is requesting a new loan in order to buy more merchandise and materials for selling ice cream. Enrique plans to distribute his product to various shopping centers throughout the city. He does not have the money needed to make this investment, so he is requesting your cooperation through another loan. This investment in his business will allow him to generate more income, which he will use to repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for making ice cream

loans.name: Sabali Kagni Group

texts.fr:
Les sept  femmes du groupe SABALIKAGNI sont toutes mariées,  avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et 2 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames  à Siekourani un village de la sous préfecture de LOULOUNI   région de Sikasso 3 e région du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur troisième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’agrandir leurs activités et leur chiffre d’affaire. 
Ce groupe de femme fait le commerce de céréales, d’habillements, de fruits et légumes, de condiments et des tubercules tels l’igname avec  avec Mariam Konaté.
MARIAM K. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  30 sacs de 50 kg  d’igname. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Loulouni et  dans les foires des villages voisins. 
L’igname est  revendu en détail au marché de Loulouni à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.. 
 Elle  envisage   réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne pour des fins sociaux et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités commerciales.
texts.en:
The seven women of the Sabalikagni group are all married with two children each, and an average age of 37. They mainly live in polygamous families in Siekourani, a village in the sub-prefecture of Loulouni, Sikasso - the third largest region in Mali.
