loans.name: Bernadeth

texts.en:
Bernadeth, 44, a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. requested a loan of 6,000 Php as additional capital for her business in corn farming. She tills 1 hectare of corn field in Banga, South Cotabato and also owns 2 cows. She maintains the farm very well to have a plentiful harvest. 

She started corn farming in 1985. She now has 4 children; her eldest is 24 years old. With corn farming, she was able to provide the basic needs of her family. This loan will help a lot to purchase farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Jilyn

texts.en: Jilyn, 24, a resident of Banga, South Cotabato is a rice farmer. She manages a 2-hectare rice field, which is her main source of income. She has a 3-year-old child to support. She lacks capital, and that's why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and requested a loan of 6,000 Php. This loan will help her a lot in providing fertilizers for her rice field.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en: Juvy, 43, is a rice farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. She needs farm inputs for her rice field. But she lacks capital, and that's why she sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., requesting a loan of 6,000 Php. This loan will enable her to provide the supplies needed for her farm. She is a mother of 2 children. Rice farming is the only way she can provide the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim Y., 58, is an older woman who lives with her husband and seven of her children in Takeo province. She grows rice, but her plantation is just enough to support her family members. Her husband is a fisherman. He catches and sells fish at the local market. On average, he is able to make about US$ 2.50 in profit a day. Three of the children are in school, while two are construction workers. 

Every month, Kim Y. spends about US$ 30 on food, US$ 5 on utilities, US$ 15 on her children's education, US$ 5 on family transportation and another US$ 15 on miscellaneous. So to reduce their transportation costs, Kim Y. needs to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Marianita

texts.en: Marianita, 58, is a rice farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. She also owns a piggery as additional income for her family. She is a mother of 7 children. She started her business in 1970. She's now requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. for 6,000 Php. This will enable her to buy farm supplies and feed for her pigs.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann owns a corn field that is 1 hectare and ¼ rice field.  She’s 29 years old and works at her rice and corn farming business in Banga, South Cotabato.  She started her business way back in 2008.  With the income she receives from her farm, the financial problems in sustaining the needs of her family are met.  

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to access a loan for her farm.  She requested the amount of 6,000 Php as additional capital to finance her business.  With this amount, she can buy fertilizers, seeds, and other farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila, 58, is a corn farmer from Banga, South Cotabato.  She manages a 1-hectare corn field.  She supports her family of 9 children; the eldest is 36 years old.  She works hard in order to have a good harvest.

She has limited capital, that’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to access a loan.  She’s requesting 6,000 Php to support her business in buying seeds and farm materials.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson, 48, is living in Banga, South Cotabato and has a rice farming business.  He devotes his time to working in his 1-hectare rice field.  He heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc. that offers financial support to entrepreneurs like him, and he later joined.

His business is continually growing and now he is requesting a loan of 6,000 Php.  This amount will be helpful to sustain his business with a low interest charge.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita S., is from the village of Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Rosita owns and operates a grocery store. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rosita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional grocery stock. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional grocery stock. This will be her 4th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery stock

loans.name: Remylin

texts.en:
The rice farming business of Remylin is improving with the financial help offered by microfinance institutions.  She is 36 years old and a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., an MFI.  She is able to finance her business with a small interest charge.

Now she has requested a loan of 6,000 Php to continue to support her rice field.  She is glad that her daily needs are met by the income she receives.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem C., 38, lives with her husband and five of her children in Takeo province. She grows rice, but her plantation is just enough to support her family members. Her husband is a construction worker building houses. He has been doing this business since the year 2000. On average, he is able to make about US$ 4 in profit a day. Two of their children are in school, whilst three are construction workers. Every month, Hem C. spends about US$ 30 on food, US$ 3 on utilities, US$ 15 on her children's education, US$ 15 on family transportation and other US$ 20 on miscellaneous items. To reduce transportation costs, Hem C. needs to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Rena

texts.en:
Rena, 28, is into corn farming business. She started her business way back in 2005.  She is now managing a 1/2-hectare corn field in Banga, South Cotabato.  She loves her work in the farm.  She is the mother of a 6-year-old child.  She strives hard in order to provide the basic needs of the family.

She requested a loan of 5,000 Php from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to help in financing her farm.  With this amount, she will be able to buy seeds and farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Ritchell

texts.en: Ritchel is a corn farmer in Banga, South Cotabato.  She is 24 years old with 2 children.  She is able to sustain her family through her farm.  She manages a corn field that is 1 hectare.  Now she needs financial assistance, that’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to access a loan with low interest.  She requested 6,000 Php to improve her farm and buy farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en: Sharon, 26 years old, has businesses in rice farming and hog-raising located in Banga, South Cotabato.  She has a child that is 6 years old. To help finance her business, she has asked for a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. since it provides the lowest interest rate as compared to others. This loan will help her purchase farm supplies and feed for her pigs.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en: Mrs. Lilia M., 48 years of age, is married and is a resident of Sta. Cruz, Tangub City. She is married to Manolo M., a carpenter, and is blessed with three children who all are now of school age. To help her husband in supporting their family, Lilia decided to engage in business. She has a sari-sari (variety) store located near the government elementary school of her village. For six years, already, she has been able to manage her business and now she is earning an average net income of not less than P3,500 a month, which is so helpful to her family income. Lilia joined the cooperative in 2007. As an active member of the PDP-LP Program (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) of Paglaum MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she was able to obtain multiple loan amounts. Her previous loan was P14,900. This time, Lilia is requesting P20,000 as her 7th loan to add to the capital of her sari-sari store. The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions of her family, to meet their basic needs, and for the education of her children for their better future. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

location.town: Sta. Cruz, Tangub, City, Misamis Occidental, Minda

loans.name: Warlito

texts.en: Warlito, 53, is a rice farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. He also raises ducks for additional income. He needs to purchase feed and fertilizers for his businesses. With limited capital, he requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. of 6,000 Php. He supports his family through these businesses. He has 5 children in the family to support.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Sheila Alona

texts.en: Sheila Alona R., is from the village of Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old, is separated, and has three school-aged children. Sheila owns and operates a fish-vending business. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Sheila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital to purchase more fish to sell. Sheila plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Tharl

texts.en:
Tharl P., 33, has a business selling brooms at the local market of Takeo province to earn approximately around US$ 2 each day, whilst her husband, pictured here, sells salt and is able to make US$ 6  a day. Her brooms are made from long grass which grows in the forest. 

Tharl P. learned how to make brooms from her neighbors and she started doing this business in 1997. This couple together has two children. She told a loan officer that every month she needs to spend around US$ 80 on food and US$ 5 on utilities. 

Tharl P. is asking for a loan to purchase salt for her husband to resell.

loans.use: To purchase salt to sell

loans.name: Erdenechimeg

texts.en:
Erdenechimeg B. is 31 years-old and the married mother of a six year-old son. She and her family live together in a ger (a Mongolian nomadic tent) in a rented yard in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son, Temuge, attends a local kindergarten. Erdenechimeg earns her living by selling food products with her husband at a local market called Bayanzurh. 

When she began her retail business, her working capital was 500,000 tugrugs (~  360 USD) and now, as a result of hard work, it has increased to 700,000 tugrugs (~ 500 USD) in only three years. However, she still needs to increase her working capital in order to expand her product line and grow her business. Erdenechimeg earns 224,000 tugrug (~  160 USD) monthly from her business and pays for her family's expenses. She is a polite person who has good communication skills. Erdenechimeg would like to purchase her own place to live with her family and provide better living conditions for her only son. She is requesting a 700,000 tugrug (~  525 USD) loan to purchase a variety of food products including preserved cucumbers, tea, sugar, rice and mayonnaise for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Sous

texts.en:
Sous N. H. is 24 years-old and lives with her parents in Takeo province. She is unmarried and works as a garment factory worker. She has been working for about three years and is able to make US $2 each day.

Sous N. H. is asking for a loan of US $600 to fix her leaking roof that poses a problem during the rainy season.

loans.use: To fix a roof leak.

loans.name: Tsogzolmaa

texts.en:
Tsogzolmaa B. is 45 years-old and lives with her husband and three children in Zavhan province, Mongolia, in an apartment. Her youngest daughter, Naranzul, attends university. Her two sons have graduated from their university and are working. When Tsogzolmaa's sons have spare time they help with their parent's businesses.

Tsogzolmaa's husband, Sandagdorj, operates a transportation business. Since 2002, Tsogzolmaa has operated a cafe and she has steadily expanded her business and built a loyal customer base over the past eight years. Since she started her business, her family's living condition has improved. 

Tsogzolmaa is a very enthusiastic person who has been working hard to provide a better life for her family. She is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug (~ 1800 USD) loan to purchase food products to resell to the local residents of her area.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Sum L., 50, is a widow who lives with one of her children in Takeo province. She sells fruit at the local market to earn a living and is able to make about US $3 profit a day. Her son is a local teacher. He teaches at state school and makes US $6 a day.  

Sum L. wants to have more income to help raise her standard of living, so she is asking for a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a car so that her son can operate a taxi. Her son will resign from being a teacher soon and start running a taxi instead. (Sum L. is pictured with her son at home.)

loans.use: To purchase a taxi.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bayarjargal

texts.en:
Bayrjargal is a widow with two children. She lives with her 21-year-old son and 22-year-old daughter in Zavhan province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. Both of her children are university students, and during their summer holidays they come to their mother and help with her business. Bayarjargal operates a vegetable trading business in her town. She has been operating her business for 17 years and has steadily expanded her business.  

Bayarjargal harvests seven tons of vegetables from her own plot of land each year. She has been planning to purchase more land to grow vegetables as well. She is a very hardworking businesswoman. Besides her business, she manufactures Buriad-style boots in order to earn extra income for her family. With her business profit, she has been paying for her two children's university tuition fees and providing money for her family expenses. Bayarjargal is a great mother who has been working hard to provide a better life and education for her two children. She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~  1075 USD) loan to purchase irrigation equipment for her business.

loans.use: To purchase irrigation equipment.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn L. is from the village of Bocator Tangub City. She is 32 years-old and married with three school-aged children. Evelyn owns and operates a  specialized retail store which sells daily use products such as candies, eggs, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Evelyn joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Evelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia P. is from the village of Sta. Maria Tangub City. She is 46 years-old and married with three school-aged children.   Ofelia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from raising pigs for sale. Ofelia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Ofelia joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ofelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. Ofelia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and then sell in the future. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ofelia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock.

loans.name: Gansuh

texts.en: Gansuh is 28 and the married father of a seven year-old son. He and his family live in a ger (a Mongolian nomadic tent ) in Arhangai province, Mongolia. Since 2008, Gansuh has operated a trading business and has been steadily expanding his business. Today, his working capital is 1,500,000 tugrugs (~ 1070 USD). His working capital has doubled since he opened his business.  Gansuh would like to expand his product line with new goods from China to provide a wider selection for his customers. He has started to build a house for his family, and successfully operating his business will allow him to finish building the house. He has a great business mind and is focused on  the future. Gansuh would like to open his own shop in the future. He is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~ 450 USD) loan to purchase additional inventory in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Sear

texts.en:
Sear P. is 24 years-old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker who is able to make US $2 profit every day. Her husband has a business selling wood. He has been doing this business since 2005 and is able to make US $3 per day. 

Sear P. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase cows and a trailer for her husband to transport wood to sell.

loans.use: To purchase cows and a trailer.

loans.name: Demberelsuren

texts.en:
Demberelsuren G. is 52 and the married father of two children. He and his family live together in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic tent, in Zavhan province, Mongolia. 

Demberelsuren operates a transportation and mobile trading business. He transports local residents to and from many different areas. He has been operating his businesses since 2007, and has steadily expanded his business and built a loyal customer base. Between 2004 and 2007, Demberelsuren operated a raw materials trading business. He is an industrious person, a good salesman, and has excellent communication skills. 

In the future, Demberelsuren would like to expand his business and repair his car. He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~ 1075 USD) loan to purchase fodder and consumer products to sell to local herder families.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en:
Bonifacia M. has been dedicated since she was very young to engage in a hog-fattening business. Presently, she relies on this activity to cover her personal costs and to help sustain her family.

Bonifacia buys piglets from her neighbors, raises them, and when they have reached a good point of development, she sells them to business people who visit the village. This activity is very common in their location and many entrepreneurs do this.

Bonifacia wishes to expand her business by buying more piglets, vitamins and feed, in order to forge ahead with her business and be able to help her family to get ahead. For this reason, she is for the first time requesting a Kiva loan of 20,000 Php through ASHI to help her reach her goal.

Bonifacia is a hardworking woman who is dedicated to her home. Her dream is to care for her three children and offer them a better quality of life. Her neighbors, friends, and even her group mates consider her an agreeable and respectful person.

Bonifacia’s dreams are to provide a better future for her family, to sustain the profitability of her business, and to start a savings account for her children and support them in finishing their studies until they complete college and find good jobs.

Through hard work and determination, Bonifacia is focused on improving her quality of life through her entrepreneurial initiatives with support from ASHI and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, vitamins and pig feed

loans.name: Janchiv

texts.en:
Janchiv L. is 27, married and has a 2-year-old child. He and his family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent. They live in Arhangai, one of Mongolia's central provinces. 

Janchiv operates a carpentry business with his wife. They have been operating their business since 2007, and have steadily expanded. In 2007, he started his business, with an initial investment of 200,000 tugrugs (~  140 USD). As a result of three years' hard work, his working capital has increased to 2,000,000 tugrug (~ 1430 USD). With his earnings, he has been able to purchase his own plot of land with a house and yard for his family. 

Janchiv purchases his raw materials in Tsenher soum (a local administrative unit ). Janchiv is an enthusiastic person who has a great business mind and excellent communication skills. He says, “I would like to create my own workshop and hire a few employees for my business in the future.” He is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug (~  1785 USD) loan to support his business.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Togtohtuya

texts.en:
Togtohtuya D. is 30, married, and the mother of a 6-year-old son. She and her family live together in a house, which they own, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son, Chingunjav, attends a local kindergarten. 

Togtohtuya operates a tire repair service with her husband. Her husband, Amarsanaa, used to work in a tire-repairing place. Afterwards, he had the idea to run his own tire repair service and implemented his idea in 2006. 

Togtohtuya and her husband have been successfully operating their business, and expanded their business by operating their service in another location as well. In addition, they hired two employees for their business. 

Togtohtuya and her family have been planning to grow their business in the future.  Togtohtuya is a helpful person with a good personality. She says, “My dream is one day to change my tire repair place into a large auto repair service.” She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to repair and furnish her house. Their stove has a problem with emitting lot of smoke which is uncomfortable and unhealthy for her family.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Dith

texts.en: Dith K. is 54 years old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She grows and sells vegetables at the local market to earn a living and is able to make about US$ 2 in profit a day, whilst her husband is a construction worker. On average, he makes US$ 3 per day. This couple has six children; two are in school and three are employed as garment factory workers. Dith K. would like to take out a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase wood to finish her construction.

loans.use: house improvement

loans.name: Galsanpuntsag

texts.en:
Galsanpuntsag is 34 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent. Two of his children, ages 14 and 15, attend a local secondary school. His youngest daughter attends local primary school. 

Galsanpuntsag operates a business making gold and silver goods in his town. From 1991- 2002,  he was a herder with a few head of livestock and operated his gold and silver crafts business from his home. Since 2005,  he has been operating only his gold and silver goods business, after he ran a grocery store for a year. 

He says, “Since I received the loan, my family's living conditions have improved. I improved my old workplace and increased my working capital. I have been planning to build a workplace at a local market.”  Galsanpuntsag is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase necessary materials to build a workplace for his business.

loans.use: To purchase materials to build a workplace

loans.name: Sa Kun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sa Kun K. is from Krang Koam village in Kandal province. She is 34 years old and is the village bank president of her group loan which consists of thirteen members. Each member of this village loan will use their share to purchase equipment, supplies, and other items to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Sa Kun K. is a seamstress in a garment factory while her husband, Mr. Eak C. is a grocery seller. With these two businesses they can earn a small income to support their family. Mrs. Sa Kun K. now is requesting a loan to buy more groceries to support her husband's business activity. This couple has five children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory while the other four are attending the local school.

loans.use: buy more groceries for her husband's business

loans.name: Vannak's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Vannak D. is 44 years old and is the village bank president of his group consisting of fourteen people, located in Krang Koam village in Kandal province. Each member of the group will use the loan for different purposes and hopes to increase income to improve his or her family's standard of living.

Mr. Vannak D. is a motorbike taxi driver and his wife, Mrs. Srey Mom Chhorn, is a seamstress in a garment factory. With these two businesses, they earn a small income to support their family. Mr. Vannak D. is now requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding. With this new business, he hopes to increase income to improve his family's standard of living. This couple has four children: two are seamstresses in the garment factory while the other two attend the local school.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Nem

texts.en:
Mrs. Nem K. and her husband, Mr. Pann Mean (pictured together), live in a small village located approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1971 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. Three of their children are married and live in separate homes; one son is a fisherman, one drives a horse cart and one attends school. 

Nem has been selling fish for more than ten years.  Her husband has been driving a horse cart for more than five years. She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase fishing nets for her son who is a fisherman.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets for her son’s fishing business

loans.name: Manith

texts.en:
Mrs. Manith N., 27, and her husband, Mr. Sophat Noun, 31, have been married since 2004 and have two sons. One of them attends school and the other is still young and stays at home. The family lives in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh.  

Manith has been selling fish for over one year and also raises pigs at home. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase additional piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Teap

texts.en: Teap M. is 40 years old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She makes cow ties and sells them to the local market to earn approximately US$10 in revenue each day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver who earns, on average, US$3 every day. This couple has four children living at home to support. Teap M. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase ties and more materials to make more cow ties.

loans.use: to make cow ties

loans.name: Houch

texts.en:
Mr. Houch I., 24, and his wife, Mrs. Mom Eng, 25, live in a small village off of National Road Number Two, about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They were married in 2007 and have a young daughter. 

Houch has been a blacksmith for three years. His wife is a construction worker. He is asking for his first loan of $150 to fill up the land under his house.

loans.use: To fill up the land under his house.

loans.name: Sinoeurn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinoeurn H. is a 34-year-old married woman and the leader of her group loan consisting of eight members, located in Preak Ta Choar village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Sinoeurn H. is a Khmer noodle seller and her husband, Mr. Sopheak Houn, is a construction worker. They both earn a small income to support their family. Mrs. Sinoeurn H. is now requesting a loan to buy pillars to build her house. This couple has a child who is a student in the local school.

loans.use: to buy pillars to build her house

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia is a 28-year-old lady living in Hoima, Uganda. She operates a secretarial shop in the heart of the town. She is married to a civil servant and together they have one child, age 2. She dreams of constructing her own family home. She says renting is very expensive yet uncomfortable. She wants to expand on the business opportunities of her secretarial shop by adding stationery so as to have an all-round station for secretarial services and stationery. 

Sylvia got to know about HOFOKAM through a friend who advised her to inject additional capital into her shop to progress to the next level. She intends to use the loan funds to buy books, pencils, pens, rulers and printing paper among other things to add to her secretarial services shop.

loans.use: To buy books, pencils, pens, rulers and printing paper among other things to add to her secretarial services shop

loans.name: Karn

texts.en: Karn S. is 29 years old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She typically earns a profit of US$1.60 a day, making cow ties. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver who earns, on average, US$5 per day. This couple has three children. Every month, Karn S. spends around US$40 on food and US$5 on utilities. Karn S. is asking for a loan of US$800 to replace an old and unreliable motorbike for her husband.

loans.use: to replace an old and unreliable motorbike

loans.name: Sophan

texts.en:
Mr. Sophan B., 43, and his wife, Mrs. Sambo Soun, 43, live in a small village along National Road Number Three, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1990 and have five children: four sons and one daughter. One of their sons is a driver and two have full-time employment.  
 
Sophan has been a construction worker for 22 years. His wife has been a garment factory worker for ten years. He is asking for his first loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike to get work.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Leakhena

texts.en:
Mrs. Leakhena K., 28, and her husband, Mr. Nob Nheb, 33, live in a small village along National Road Number Three, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2002 and have two daughters, both still young. Leakhena also has her elderly mother living with her. 
 
Leakhena has been a garment factory worker for 14 years. Her husband is a construction worker. She is applying for her first loan of $400 to purchase construction materials for her brother’s construction business.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for her brother’s construction business

loans.name: Hean's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hean T. is 56 years old and the village bank president selected by the eleven members of this group loan, located I. Preak Ta Choar village I. Kandal province. Each member of the group will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Hean T. and her husband, Mr. Hov Khay, are farmers who own a plot of land to grow vegetables. Mrs. Hean T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a watering machine for the crops; she will use the rest of the loan to grow vegetables. This couple has four children: one is a farm laborer and three are students who also support their parents' business.

loans.use: to buy a watering machine

loans.name: Eat

texts.en: Eat O. is 40 years old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She and her husband together raise and sell pigs for a profit of US$4 a day. The couple has five children living at home to support. Every month, Eat O. spends about US$45 on food, US$7 on utilities, US$35 on transportation and US$40 on miscellaneous expenses. To earn more money, Eat O. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 so that she can raise more pigs.

loans.use: to raise more pigs

loans.name: Sophy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophy K. is from Preak Ta Choar village in Kandal province. She is 40 years old and the village bank president of her group, which consists of twelve people. The members of this village group will use the loan to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Sophy K. and her husband, Mr. RA Yorn, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice and vegetables. Mrs. Sophy K. decided to ask for a loan to support her vegetable crops. She is the mother of four children: one is a farm laborer while the other three are students in the local school who also support their parents' farming.

loans.use: to support her vegetable crops

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
To make a living, for over 20 years Victoria has owned and operated a business raising pigs for sale, earning consistently good profits. In 2006 she joined ASHI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan from ASHI that was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies, Victoria is now requesting a new loan, her fifth, of 20,000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and additional piglets for more revenue. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. This will allow Victoria to further grow her hog-raising business so that her children fulfill their dreams of completing college degrees and finding better jobs and giving her family a decent life.

Her long term goal is to purchase additional raw materials for her fishing business (a secondary business) so she can expand and sell more fish in the local community and other surrounding neighborhoods. She also hopes to have a successful pig farm someday.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and additional piglets for more income.

loans.name: Srey Chou's Group

texts.en:
This group loan, consisting of eleven people, is located in Preak Ta Choar village in Kandal province. Mrs. Srey Chou C. is a 27-year-old married woman and the village bank president selected by all the members. Each member of this village group will use the loan to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Srey Chou C. and her husband, Mr. Hoeun Hieng, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate vegetables. Mrs. Srey Chou C. is also a vegetable seller who earns a small income to support her family. Since her vegetable selling is going well, she wants to expand it. She decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. This couple has three children: two attend the local school while the youngest one is 4 years old.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Sany's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sany L., 48, is the village bank president selected by the sixteen members of the group loan, located in Spean Dek village in Kandal province. Each member of this village group will use the loan to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Sany L. is a drink seller who earns a small income to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. She decided to ask for a loan to buy more drinks to enlarge her business; she wants to use the rest of the loan to buy soil to fill in her yard. Her husband, Mr. Kranh Art, is a fisherman who can support his family a little with his small income. This couple has six children: two are laborers, one is a drink seller, one is a student at the local school and two are too young to study or work.

loans.use: to buy more drinks

loans.name: Seark

texts.en: Seark N. is 28 years old and lives with her husband and two young children in Takeo province. She stays at home and makes silk scarves to sell at the local market and is able to make about US$2.30 of profit a day. Her husband is a construction worker who builds houses. On average, he makes US$3 a day. Seark N. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase more silk.

loans.use: Purchase silk.

loans.name: Mamaeva Zebi Group

texts.ru:
Все эти замечательные и трудолюбивые женщины работают и живут в Узгенском районе. Группа в этом составе подучает уже третий кредит в Мол Булак Финанс. Все предыдущие кредиты они отработали очень хорошо. Каждая из них преследует свою цель при получении кредита в МБФ, однако у всех имеется единственное стремление - улучшить свое благосостояние и обеспечить своих детей наилучшим образом. Начнем презентацию группы с лидера.

Зеби, 61, замужем. Ее супруг работает ветеринаром в селе. От него зависит не только здоровье скота, но и благосостояние населения села. Так как урон скоту, означает урон доходам семьям, которые проживают здесь. Клиент сама также занимается животноводством. Этот кредит она планирует потратить на приобретение барана  и одного теленка. 

Гулнара, 55, замужем. Ее супруг работает охранником в местной щколе. У нее 8 детей: 6 дочерей и 2 сына. Большинство участников занимаются разведением и откормом домашнего скота, Гулнара тоже не исключение. Этим бизнесом она занимается с 1976 года. Сейчас она хочет купить корову с теленком, чтобы получать и продавать молоко и молочные изделия. 

Эркин 56 лет. До этого она занималась земледелием, выращивала табак. Сейчас она занята животноводством. В бизнесе ей помогают дети и супруг. Цель кредит - приобретение КРС. 

Савирахон - вдова с 4 детьми: 3 сына и дочь. Она планирует купит барана. 

Кадича, 55, вдова. У нее двое детей, оба учится в сельской школе. Она запрашивает уже свой третий кредит для покупки барана для дальнейшего откорма. 

Бурмайым и Сайрагул, 54 и 53 соответственно. Они также хотят купить МРС, которые будут отправлены на пастбище.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
All of these remarkable and hardworking women work and live in the Uzgen district. This same group is obtaining their third credit with Mol Bulak Finance. They worked off all of the previous loans very well. Every one of the women achieve their goal by obtaining a loan with MBF, however, they all have one goal to strive for, which is to improve their welfare and provide the best for their children. Let’s begin the presentation of the group with its leader. Zebi is 61 years old. Her husband works as a veterinarian in the village. Not only does the health of livestock depend on him, but also the welfare of the village population. Losses of livestock mean losses of incomes of the families who live here. Zebi is also involved in animal husbandry. She plans to use this loan to buy a sheep and one calf. Gulnara is 55 years old, married. Her husband works as a security guard at a local school. She has 8 children: 6 daughters and 2 sons. The majority of participants are involved in breeding and fattening of domestic livestock. Gulnara is also not an exception. She has been involved in this business since 1976. Now she wants to buy a cow with a calf in order to obtain and sell dairy products. Erkin is 56 years old. She was previously involved in farming and grew tobacco. Now she is involved in animal husbandry. Her children and husband help her with the business. The goal of the loan is to buy cattle. Savirahon is a widow with 4 children. She has 3 sons and a daughter. She plans to purchase a sheep. Kadicha is 55 years old, a widow. She has two children, both of whom attend a village school. She is requesting her third loan for the purchase of a sheep for subsequent fattening. Burmayim and Sayragul are 54 and 53 years old respectively. They also want to buy small livestock that will be sent off to a pasture.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a sheep and a calf

loans.name: Fermina

texts.en:
Fermina E. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 46 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Fermina owns a general  alteration and tailoring services business. Fermina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Fermina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fermina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Fermina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family income. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn D. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 39 years old and married with six school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn sells seafood products — fish, dried, fish and shrimp. She buys seafood from different fishermen and sells it in the village. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used as additional working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
Jeanette S., 41, married to Precilo S., a construction worker, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Blessed with three children, she makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. For some time she has been managing her own barbecue stall while also selling charcoal to her neighbors.

Jeanette has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, regularly attending their weekly fellowship meetings and paying her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. Jeanette is consistent in paying her dues because she has used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.

To ensure her continued business success, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan to buy the raw ingredients needed to continue production of her barbecue and charcoal businesses. Jeanette dreams that her enterprises will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy the raw ingredients needed to continue production of her barbecue and her charcoal businesses.

loans.name: Bernardina

texts.en:
Over the years, Bernardina A. has provided for her family by raising hogs (including slaughtering) and, more than five years ago, embarking on a fishing business. The profit from these businesses has been the main source of family income. Now Bernardina has access to working capital, her profits are better than before.
Bernardina is requesting another loan from Kiva partner, ASHI, for the much larger amount of 20,000 PHP. She will use this loan to construct a new fish cage for her fishing business and to maintain her hog-raising business. This will allow her to grow her businesses further in order for her children to fulfill their dreams of completing college degrees and finding good jobs.
Bernardina's long-term goals are to build sustainable businesses and construct a more durable home that can survive the flooding that is common in her village. With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her income-generating activities will provide a steady income to improve her financial stability and give her family a better life. Bernardina’s biggest dream is to have a successful pig farm and fish farm someday. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. Her two businesses are the best ways to provide for her family and she very much wants to lift her family out of the cycle of poverty.

loans.use: To construct a new fish cage and maintain her hog-raising business

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria R. is from the village of San Isidro, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 41 years old and married with seven school-aged children. To make a living, Victoria runs a sari-sari (variety) shop selling both food and daily use products. Victoria has been engaged in her business for several years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Victoria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Victoria from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mathnilla

texts.en:
Mathnilla R. is from the village of San Isidro, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 51 years old and married with two adult children. To make a living, Mathnilla is starting a business making and selling food such as snacks and other delicacies. 

In 2010, Mathnilla joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Mathnilla from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement  her family's income. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia M., 57, is married to Ricardo M., a farmer. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life by managing her own fruit stand.

Virginia has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s Cooperative. She uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her fruit business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan to replenish and maintain her fruit inventory. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a happy and comfortable life for her family.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.name: Ginalyn

texts.en: Ginalyn R.'s main source of income comes from making and selling snacks and delicacies like ube jam, banana que and fried sweet potato in her community. She is 23 years old, married and has one small child. They are from the village of San Isidro, Talakag, Bukidnon. Ginalyn is just starting this business. In 2010, Ginalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Ginalyn is requesting a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. loans.name: Modesto

texts.en:
Modesto D., 43, is making sure that his family has enough provisions for their daily needs. He makes sure that he provides well so that his family can have a better life. He has been managing his own fruit stand for quite some time now.

Modesto has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. He regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays his weekly dues consistently. Because of his good repayment performance with his previous loans, he was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. He is consistent in paying his dues because he uses the money he borrows to expand and improve his business.

Now with your help, he would like to access a 10,000 Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital for his expanding business to buy larger quantities of his regular products and new products needed to continue his business operations. He dreams that his business will continue to grow so that he can have a good and comfortable life with his family.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy products needed to continue his business operations

In 2010, Genevie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genevie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase ingredients that she needs to make products to sell. This will be Genevie's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.name: Anjelina

texts.en:
Anjelina F. sells beans and tomatoes. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice to sell.  Anjelina is 39 years old and is married to a clerk. She has 4 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

In 2010, Baltazar joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Baltazar is requesting a  loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional bamboo products to sell. This will be Baltazar's first loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his children's education. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng S., age 23, is married and resides with her husband and six-year-old child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She is a farmer who grows rice. She earns an income of about USD $3.00 per day. Her husband is often hired to pick fruit and is also a farmer. He earns an income of USD $5.00 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

S. is requesting a loan of USD $1000 to purchase a new sewing machine to start a home tailoring business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine to start a home tailoring business

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Neang S. is 23 years old and lives with his parents in the Takeo Province. He is not married yet and work as a veterinarian. In addition, he is has a business making rice wine and raising chickens. On average, he makes US $5.00 per day. 

Neang S. is asking for a loan of US $1200 to purchase rice and buy more tools to make rice wine.

loans.use: To buy rice and tools to make rice wine

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina R., already a widow at sixty, is making sure that her family has enough to meet their daily needs. She has been managing her own mini arcade for quite some time now.

Avelina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues, and she has used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a loan of 9,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital so she can expand her business by purchasing another Playstation unit.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase an additional Playstation unit

loans.name: Nyachan

texts.en:
Nyachan R. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at a restaurant, and she is requesting a loan to help her stock more rice and maize flour. Nyachan is twenty-nine years old and is married to a policeman. She has two children, who are in school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a pharmacy.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward helping returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To help her stock more rice and maize flour

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en:
Nimfa D. R. is from the village of Pagalungan, Wao Lanao D. Sur. She is forty-eight years old. Nimfa is married and has three grown children. To make a living, Nimfa owns and operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling dry goods, including children's toys and other items, in the local community. Nimfa has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nimfa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nimfa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. Nimfa is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Nimfa's fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Tsetsegmaa

texts.en: Tsetsegmaa M. is thirty-seven years old, married, and the mother of three. She and her family live together in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic tent, in Arhangai province, Mongolia. Tsetsegmaa operates a meat-trading business at a local market. She has been operating her business since 1997, and she has expanded her business steadily. When she began her business, her working capital was 50,000 MNT, and now, as a result of hard work, it has increased to 620,000 MNT. Tsetsegmaa built a new house with her business profits in 2007. She is an open and very hardworking person. Tsetsegmaa says, “With my business profit, I have been able to allow money for my oldest son's medical treatment which he has to have every year. In addition, I have been providing money for my family expenses.” Tsetsegmaa is requesting a loan of 600,000 MNT, with which she will purchase a variety of meat at wholesale prices for resale at her counter.

loans.use: To purchase meat to sell

loans.name: Modi

texts.en:
Modi H. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and firewood at home and is requesting a loan to help her stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Modi is thirty-five years old and is married to a soldier. She has two children, who are in school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs, as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward assisting returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcaol to sell

loans.name: Yuliya

texts.en:
Yuliya owns a retail business that sells various agricultural products, including seeds, fertilizers, and bug killers. Yuliya has a large assortment of products, affordable prices, and a good reputation at the market. She has many repeat clients who buy items from her to use on their gardens.

Yuliya has been in this business for thirteen years. The business is seasonal; she sells most of her items in spring and summer. In this particular area, many people grow a lot of vegetables, so Yuliya's business is very useful to them. 

Yuliya would like to borrow 20,000 UAH to purchase seasonal inventories--seeds and fertilizers. She hopes to develop her business even more and to have more clients who will use her services. Yuliya lives with her husband, Alexander, and her son and daughter. Their son is a college student.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Chiti

texts.en:
Chiti R. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions, and groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes and cooking oil to sell. Chiti is thirty years old and is married; her husband is a nurse. She has three children, who are in school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward assisting returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock Irish potatoes and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Mary Saint

texts.en:
Mary Saint G. is from the village of Francfort, Bumbaran Lanao Del Sur. She is twenty-seven years old. Mary Saint is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Saint owns and operates a fruit stand. The main source of income for her business comes primarily from selling variety of fruit in the local community. Mary Saint has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mary Saint joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Saint has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Mary Saint is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Mary Saint's third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Munhtsetseg

texts.en: Munhtsetseg D. is twenty-seven years old. She is single and lives with her mother in a ger (a Mongolian nomadic tent), in Arhangai, Mongolia. Munhtsetseg operates a mobile product-trading business in her town. She started her business with her brother in 2004; she purchases a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border town, and sells them to the herder families. Munhtsetseg sells her products in Burd, Orhon bags (a local small administrative unit) in Tsenher Soum. In the beginning, she purchased 80,000 MNT worth of products for her business. However, with a lot of hard work and determination, today her working capital is 3,500,000 MNT. With her earnings, Munhtsetseg purchased her own plot of land with a house and yard for her family in 2006. In addition, she purchased a new car with her business profit. She is a very hardworking person and her dream is one day to create her own shop. Munhtsetseg is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to purchase a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border town, at wholesales prices and to resell them for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase variety of products to sell

loans.name: Ben

texts.en: Ben S., twenty-four, is married and resides with her husband and three-year-old child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She grows watermelons and rice for an income of about 2 USD per day. Her husband is a construction worker; he earns an income of 5 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. S. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work and to provide motor-taxi services. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. his is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.name: Dagvadorj

texts.en:
DagvaD. D. is a 63-year-old widower. He lives alone in a "ger" (a yurt or Mongolian nomadic housing tent) in Arhangai, one of Mongolia's central provinces. 

DavgaD. operates a taxi service in his town. He has operated an inter-city transportation business for many years, beginnin when he was very young. He has been running his taxi service since 2001 and is an experienced driver. DavgaD. says, "Operating a business and being active helps me to stay healthy and be happy." 

He is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan to purchase four tires and other spare parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase tires and spare parts for his car

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en:
Pheng S., age 24, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells groceries and grows rice for an income of about USD $12 per day. Her husband always helps his wife in both work at the field and at home. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD $500 to purchase more groceries to stock her store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her business.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband's appears in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Yolany

texts.en:
Yolany F. is from the village of West Pob. Kal. Bukidnon. She is 31 years old. Yolany is single and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Yolany sells clothing and shoes in the local community. Yolany has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Yolany joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolany has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. Yolany is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be Yolany's 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

They do not have enough money to support their farm. Thus, Mrs. Kosall Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, vegetable seeds and gasoline to support her farm. This couple has seven children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a farmer, one is a student in a local school and the others are between 2 and 5 years old.

As rice farmers, they have a problem because their field is ready for farming, but they did not have enough money to support it. Thus, Mr. Art O. decided to ask for a loan to do farming this year. Sout M., 32, is married and lives with her two young children in the Siem Reap province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband, pictured here, has a business recharging batteries making US$3 each day. 

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, which has caused tough economic times for many Cambodians, Sout M. included. In light of this economic difficulty, she has requested a loan of US$550 to expand her farmland. In order to increase her profits and possibly raise her standard of living, she would like to purchase more land to produce rice with the loan given to her through CREDIT. M.'s husband appears in the photograph.

Mrs. Sokhom T. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her child. Her current problem is that her house is too old to live in, but she did not have enough money to make the necessary repairs. Thus, Mrs. Sokhom T. requested this loan to fix her house. She is widow with two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory while the other is studying in local public school.

Aside from selling this produce, Mrs. Seng P. is also a dessert seller. With these businesses they are able to earn a small income to support their family's living expenses. 

Mrs. Seng P. has now requested a loan to buy more vegetables to enlarge her business activities. She also wants to use part of the loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides to support her husband's farming. This couple has four children, two of whom are vegetable sellers who support their mother's business. One other is a student in the local school while the last one is staying at home.
