To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling a variety of different products in the local community with the assistance of her husband. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her house. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To  invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Soy C., 30, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She produces baskets for sale for an income of about USD 2.50 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  C. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to purchase more plastics to produce plastic baskets for new and existing customers. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy plastic to produce plastic baskets

loans.name: Chanthoeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthoeun C. is a 28-year-old married woman. She is the village bank president selected by 14 members, located in Kaoh P. village in Kandal province. Each member of this village loan group will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Chanthoeun C. is a fruit and vegetable seller who earns a small income to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Kunthea Nheom, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates vegetables.
 
Mrs. Chanthoeun C. now is requesting a loan to buy more fruits to enlarge her business and to purchase fertilizer and pesticide to support her husband's farming. Mrs. Chanthoeun C. is a mother of two children; one is attending the local school and the other one is four years old.

loans.use: To buy more fruit, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Chou

texts.en: Chou S., 48, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She produces baskets for sale for an income of about USD 3.50 per day. Her husband is a social officer, earning an income of USD 3.50 per day to help cover the family expenses.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 900 to purchase more baskets for resale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy baskets for resale

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel C. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan Cotabato. She is 25 years old. Maricel is married and has three infant children. To make a living, Maricel owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maricel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Maricel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Yan Yim Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of nine people who live in Roleang Kaen village in Kandal province. Mrs. Yan Y. is the village bank president, selected by all the members.  They will use the loan for different purposes. She owns a general store in the local village to earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it, but she does not have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Yan Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. Her husband, Mr. Chhay Duch, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow rice to support his family. Mrs. Yan Y. has two children. One of her children is a seamstress in a garment factory and one attends the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell

loans.name: Phou

texts.en: Phou R., 28, is married and resides with her husband and child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She sells porridge and boiled rice for an income of about USD 5 per day. Her husband provides money exchange services and sells gold, earning an income of USD 10 per day to help cover the family expenses. R. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to expand her husband’s businesses. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. R. is pictured with her husband.

loans.use: To expand the money exchange business

loans.name: Phem

texts.en: Phem Y., 48, is a widowed farmer who lives with one of her children in the Siem Reap province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Phem Y. included. In light of this economic difficulty, she is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a hand tractor. Phem Y. was not available for the picture so her son is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase a hand tractor.

loans.name: Bet

texts.en: Bet Y., 56, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She provides make-up services for wedding parties and sells groceries at home for an income of about USD 10 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of USD 1.50 per day to help cover the family expenses.  Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more wedding supplements to expand her business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. Y. is pictured with her husband here.

loans.use: To buy wedding supplements to expand the current business

loans.name: Hon's Group

texts.en: This group loan, which consists of 21 members, is located in Sdao Kanleng village in Kandal province. Mrs. Hon S., 50 years old, is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Hon S. is a farmer who rents some land to cultivate vegetables. She decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer and pesticide to support her farming crops. Her husband, Mr. Chhin Roth, is a laborer who receives a small salaR. to support his family. Mrs. Hon S. is a mother of six children. Two of her children are construction workers, three are seamstresses in the garment factoR., and one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng S., 55, is married and resides with her husband and three children. They live in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She raises pigs for an income of about USD $5 per day. Her husband sells sugar cane juice, earning an income of USD $5.90 per day to help cover the family's expenses.  

S. has requested a loan of USD $300 to purchase a machine to squeeze sugar cane juice. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits from the loan to make repairs to her house. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva Field Partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband is pictured at CREDIT's office in Kampong Chnang.

loans.use: To buy a machine to squeeze sugar cane juice

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David L. is 42 years old and married with four children between the ages of 8 and 19 years old. Three of the children are still attending school. He has been a dairy farmer near Litein town in the South Rift Valley of Kenya for ten years and employs two people in the community. He sells his milk at the local market but he says transport to the market is difficult due to the poor roads. He also earns some income from small-scale farming of tea, which he sells through the local Magogosiek Tea Factory.

David completed a previous loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kshs. 40,000 and has now requested this loan for Kshs. 80,000 to purchase a motorbike, primarily to transport his daily milk production to the market. He says that this will ease the transport problem for both his milk and tea and he'll be able to save extra money now spent on transport costs to help his family. 

In the future, David would like to improve his dairy farming so that he can increase production to 50 liters of milk each day.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for milk transport

loans.name: Mr. Sam Oak Eang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eleven people in RolE. Kaen village in Kandal province have joined as members of a village bank group. Mr. Sam Oak E. is a village bank president who has been selected by all the members. With the money from this loan, they will all invest in their different business ventures. 

Sam Oak and his wife are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice in order to support their family. They have two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other is studying in local public school. Although they try to work hard, they do not earn much income. Thus, Mr. Sam Oak E. requested a loan to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business. All the members are present in the picture but one of them is blocked from view.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo C., 28, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She is a tailor and is able to earn an income of about USD $7 per day. Her husband is employed at a private company, earning an income of USD $6.50 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

C. has requested a loan of USD $400 to purchase a sewing machine to expand her current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to make repairs to her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva Field Partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Celso

texts.en:
Celso L. is from the village of Justo Ramonal, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 45 years old and married with 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Celso owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, his main source of income comes primarily from selling bicycles, motorcycle parts and other car accessories in the local community. Celso has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately PHP 15,000 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Celso joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celso just successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP which was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Celso has now requested a new loan, his sixth loan cycle, for 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his retail business

location.town: Justo Ramonal, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Sem S., 31, is married and resides with her husband and one child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She raises ducks and chickens for an income of about USD $2 per day. Her husband works cutting glasses, earning an income of USD $6.50 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

S. has requested a loan of USD $1000 to purchase groceries to sell at home. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva Field Partner in Cambodia. S. and her husband are pictured together.

loans.use: To buy groceries to resell

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn G., from the village of Amoyong, Wao Lanao Del Sur, is 47 years old, married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Merlyn operates a business venture providing trucking services to local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Merlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, she is now requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be Merlyn's second loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Samrith

texts.en: Samrith P., 42, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She sells groceries for a gross income of about USD 20 per day, while her husband sells ice, earning a gross income of USD 26 per day to help cover the family expenses.  Samrith is now requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more groceries to stock the store, and in the future she would like to use any additional profit to expand her business.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Born

texts.en: Born S., 25, is married and lives with her husband in Siem Reap Province where she sells groceries, earning about US$3 each day while her husband, a recycler, makes about US$4 per day. Born S. is now requesting a loan of US$700 to expand her grocery store, an investment she is confident will increase her income.

loans.use: Expand grocery items.

loans.name: Bo

texts.en: Bo S., 26, is married and resides with her husband and child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She sells porridge and Chinese noodles for an income of about USD 2.3 per day, while her husband, a construction foreman, earns an income of USD 3.3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  Bo is now requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits earned to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. Bo is pictured with her husband here.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for commuting to work

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah C. is 48 years old, married, and the father of nine children ranging in age from 2 to 25 years old, 6 of whom are still attending school. Elijah has a mixed farm near Litein town in the South Rift Valley of Kenya. He has been dairy farming for six years, having previously just grown maize, and now sells milk directly to customers in town; in addition he cultivates tea and runs a cattle trade business. He says that the main challenges to his business are a lack of feed and suitable shelter for his cows.

Elijah has a successful history with Juhudi Kilimo, having previously completed a loan of Kshs. 45,000. He is now requesting a loan of Kshs. 50,000 to buy another dairy cow, declaring that the extra income from this loan will help him pay his children's schools fees and have a happy family. His focus is to improve his standard of living through additional income from farming.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Reynaida

texts.en:
Reynaida A. is from the village of Thailand, Banisilan Cotabato. She is 54 years old. Reynaida is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Reynaida has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately $300 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Reynaida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. She is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Theng

texts.en: Theng Y., 63, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She sells cosmetic products for an income of about $4 per day. Y. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase more cosmetic products to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more cosmetic products to sell

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda T. is from the village of Macanhan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 62 years old. Nilda is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling snack foods, bananas, coffee and other dairy products in the local community. Nilda has been engaged in her business for over three years.

In 2009, Nilda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Nilda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Macanhan, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Jonah

texts.en:
Jonah K. is a 36 year-old married man living in the South Rift Valley of Kenya, near the town of Litein. He has six children, ranging in age from less than one year to 12 years old. All the children but the youngest are currently attending school. 

Jonah has been running his mixed farm for 18 years now. He previously worked as a tea-plucker for other farmers. He now earns his income selling milk, tea, and maize. He says that lately the main challenges to his business are poor seeds, lack of water from drought and lack of sufficient feed for his livestock.

Jonah has a successful history with Juhudi Kilimo, previously completing a loan of 45,000 KES. He has now requested this loan for 60,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow and improve his overall farm activities. He says that with a good quality dairy cow he can produce enough milk to easily repay the loan and pay his children's school fees.

His main goal for the future is to purchase land and build a modern house for his family. He added, "Loans from Juhudi have helped me to progress because previously I was not able to access any credit."

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Chanthy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy C. is 51 years old and is the village bank president who was selected by all the members. She lives in Sdao Kanleng village in Kandal province.  Each member of this village loan will use it to support their different purposes. Mrs. Chanthy C. is a congee (rice porridge) and Chinese noodle seller who owns a motorcycle to support her business activities. 

She is requesting a loan to repair her motorcycle, and the rest of the loan she wants to use to support her congee business. Mrs. Chanthy C. is a widow with two children who are all students.

loans.use: to repair her motorcycle and to support her congee business.

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony is a farmer living in a town in South Cotabato. He is married to Veronica and they have three children. His eldest is aged thirteen. He supports his family through his farming. He plants corn and rice crops. He also owns a small sari-sari (variety) store, which his wife manages. 

He joined CEVI in 2008 and says that his loans were really helpful in sustaining his businesses. He also likes its insurance policy. Anthony recently applied for a loan amounting to 15,000 PHP. He will use it to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers. He also hopes to buy more products for the sari-sari store.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Talemwa Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Her market vending business is all she banks on to bring food to her family’s table. She got started after her husband gave her the startup capital thirty years ago. Being a not-so-profitable business, it has not really improved on her standard of living to her expectations. Despite this, she has strained every nerve to see to it that all her nine children get an education.

This is the story of Aisha A., a woman with a down-the-line hard work ethic. She mostly sells tomatoes, cabbages and eggplants. In her years of operating, her predominant customers have mostly been hotel owners. She has reached a rate of progress where she makes monthly profits of 50,000 shillings.

With this loan, Aisha wants to buy fresher produce to sell. She specifically wants to buy more cabbages which are in high favor with most of her clients.

loans.use: To purchase more cabbages and other highly-favoured foods

loans.name: Kum

texts.en:
Kum S., 64, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She is a farmer with an income of about $3 per day. Her husband is a farmer, too, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

S. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a water pump to water the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. is pictured with her husband.

loans.use: buy a water pump to water the rice field

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe P. is from the village of Thailand, Banisilan Cotabato. She is 44 years old and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Fe runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over thirteen years and earns approximately $300 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. Fe decided to lower her loan request to 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 9th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick B. is a 26-year-old married man living in the South Rift Valley of Kenya, near the town of Litein. He has two children, ages 5 and 7, and both are currently attending school. 

He is pictured above at his butcher shop, but he's also been running a mixed farm for four years now. He earns his income selling the milk and tea produced on his farm, and from running his butcher shop in town. He is able to employ three people in the community. He says that lately the main challenges to his business are lack of clean water, insufficient feed for his livestock and poor marketing and pricing for milk.

Erick has a successful history with Juhudi Kilimo, previously completing a loan of 40,000 KES. He has now requested this loan for 50,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow (40,000) and to expand his butchery business (10,000). He says that with the added income he'll earn he can repay the loan and also care for his family's needs.

In the future, he hopes to improve his cows to pedigree level, producing 30 liters per day, and to add to his land. He thanks Juhudi Kilimo for having improved his living standards through loans, and he promises to repay loans well so as to get another one.

loans.use: To buy a cow and make improvements to his butchery.

loans.name: Pai

texts.en:
Pai K., 25, is married and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. Selling fry birds (small, deep-fat-fried), she makes $4 each day and her husband operates a moto-taxi making $3 each day. 

She is asking for a loan of $700 to replace an old and unreliable motorbike. She sees this purchase as a good investment to expand her business and she is confident it will increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase a moto-taxi.

loans.name: Rotsie

texts.en:
Rotsie C. is from the village of Macanhan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 25 years old. Rotsie is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Rotsie owns & operates a buying and selling business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling agricultural crops like copra and bananas in the  city. Rotsie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rotsie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rotsie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as additional working capital. Rotsie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more copra and bananas to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rotsie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Macanhan, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene started to be an active entrepreneur in 2008. She invested in a rice farm and a 'sari-sari' (variety) store. Today, she has a hectare of rice field and continues to run her store. She says that by God’s grace she was able to manage the store and farm and keep it running until now. She is also thankful that her businesses have been able to sustain her family. 

Arlene is married and has three children who go to school. She hopes for her businesses to grow so she has a stable income. She applied for a loan of Php 15,000, which she will use to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers and also supplies for her 'sari-sari' store.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Boverlita

texts.en:
60-year-old Boverlita is still strong enough to manage a rice farm, grow pigs, and run a small 'sari-sari' (variety) store. She is married to Renato and they have five children. Her husband does the major farming tasks while she assists him in keeping their land free of weeds and pests. She mostly devotes her time to running the store and tending the pigs. She said that one of the reasons that she and her husband work so hard is for them to be able to have all their children finish college. She dreams for them to have bright futures. 

Boverlita is requesting for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use it to supply fertilizers for her farm, buy feed for her pigs, and also supplies for the store.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita V. is from the village of Thailand, Banisilan Cotabato. She is 64 years old. Amelita is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Amelita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Amelita has been engaged in her business for over 32 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Amelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. Amelita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Amelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bun Chhoeun's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Bun Chhoeun H. is 25 years old and is the village bank president of his group, which consists of nineteen members, located in Sdao Kanleng village in Kandal province. Each member of this village loan will use their share to purchase equipment, supplies and other items to support their different purposes. 

Mr. Bun Chhoeun H. is a grocery seller who owns a general store. With this business he can earn a small income by selling his goods to support his family. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it, thus he decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge his business. Aside from grocery selling, he is alS. a construction worker.  His wife, Mrs. Sarom Chann, is a farming laborer and alS. supports her husband's grocery selling. This couple does not have any children.

loans.use: to buy more groceries

loans.name: Usmonbek

texts.en:
C. Usmonbek is a 37-year-old businessman. He is married and together with his wife they have 4 children. Usmonbek is a farmer, like his wife. They started their work 15 years ago. The beginning was very difficult, because they needed to invest a lot of working capital. With much effort and the help of his wife, he was able to move forward and today has a large plot of land. 

His vegetables are very good quality which he says is due to the constant irrigation they receive since the business has a complete underground irrigation system. Usmonbek requests the loan for the purchase of fertilizer and seeds. This will allow him to better provide for his family.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Mr. Chab Pauk Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group loan has six people who live in Anlong Tasek Kraum village in Kandal province. Mr. Chab P. is the group leader who has been selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purposes. He and his wife, Mrs. Ra S., are farmers who own a plot of land to grow rice for supporting their family. In order to improve his family's living standards, he wants to start a new business, but he does not have enough money. Thus, Mr. Chab P. decided to ask for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding. He is a father of four children of whom all are studying in local public school.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom P., 50, is widowed and resides with two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She produces baskets for sale for an income of about USD 2 per day. Her daughter is employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike for the family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. P. is pictured with her daughter and son-in-law here.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the family use

loans.name: Saidali

texts.en:
Saidali is married and the father of 4 children. For 10 years he has been engaged in farming and cattle raising business. The love of his children is the motor that keeps him working hard for their future. He works hard together with the help of his wife to achieve quality products. The high price of fertilizer has caused his production to slow down, but he wishes to do better, have more production, and increase the number of his cattle. 

To do this, Saidali needs capital, which he requests through a loan and hopes that you can help him; this way, he can look forward to a profitable production to increase his income and pay for his children’s education.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn B. is from the village of Thailand, Banisilan Cotabato. She is 57 years old. Merlyn is widowed and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Merlyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Merlyn has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Merlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Merlyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Thun

texts.en:
Thun P., 37, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its clay and ceramic products. She is a housewife while her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of about USD 20 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is pictured here at Credit's office in Kampong Chnang.

P. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to pay for the construction worker’s labor. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To pay her husband's construction worker

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.en: D. Shuhrat is a simple farmer with simple dreams – to uplift his family’s economic life and, in future, be able to send his dearest little son to school. Farming has been Shuhrat’s major source of income; he produces rice once a year. Because of the expensive farm inputs, traders buy their rice products at too low a price. Because of this, he requests a loan of 700 USD to support his farming business and to avoid asking for credit from traders with higher interest rates. Shuhrat is grateful that he is able to borrow from lenders that offer lower interest rates, allowing borrowers to create better opportunities in their lives - thus, helping their families to be free from poverty. Shuhrat said that, through prayers and hard work, his dreams can be achieved someday. Providing his son with education is one of the important things that Shuhrat prioritizes. loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 50 years old and married to a teacher in a government school in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She has seven children, all of whom are excelling at school, and this gives her joy as a mother.
Mercy owns a medicines store where she sells medicines at retail prices to her customers. She also treats her patients when they fall ill because she is a registered nurse. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 NGN to purchase more medicines to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Sarat's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarat C. is 53 years old and has been selected as the leader of her group by the eight members who are located in Koh Chamroeun village in Kandal province. Each member of this group loan will use the loan to support a different purpose.

Mrs. Sarat C. is a fruit seller who is able to earn a small income to support her family. In this business, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fruit to enlarge her business. With this loan she hopes to increase her income to improve her family living.

Mrs. Sarat C.’s husband, Mr. Lay Loch, is a construction worker who receives a mall salary to support his family. This couple has six children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, two are laborers, while the other three are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Nena

texts.en: Nena P. is from the village of Macanhan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 49 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Nena owns and operates a specialized retail business, peddling health and medicinal products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Nena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Nena plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Oung

texts.en:
Oung N., 41, is married and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province. Raising pigs, she makes US$3 each day and her husband works as a policeman making US$3 each day as well.

Oung N. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to raise more pigs and to purchase a motorbike for her husband. She sees this purchase as a good investment to expand her business and she is confident it will increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband and to raise more pigs

loans.name: Khalifa

texts.en:
K. Khalifa, 52, is married and has four children. He lives in Djabbar Rasulov district and works with his family in the agricultural industry. Many years ago he decided to begin to cultivate land that he owned. He did so to generate more income that would enable him to support his family. 

At the same time Khalifa raises cattle near his house. He will use the loan money to buy young cattle to raise. Khalifa has discovered over the years that he enjoys doing this job, and that's why he will continue to use loans in order to improve his business.

loans.name: Ikrom

texts.en:
M. Ikrom is 24 years old. He is married and has two kids. This gentleman is a vegetable producer with more than six years of experience. Ikrom works all day on the land. He is involved in the whole production process, including post-harvest and selling. It is relevant to explain that the production of vegetables requires adequate fertilizer in order to generate the expected harvest. Nutrients and chemical fertilizers are needed throughout the process. 

Currently, Ikrom is having difficulties getting into the market with his product due to the fact that he doesn't have enough organic matter to incorporate into the soil. There isn’t enough fertilizer and the soils are poor in nutrients. It is for these reasons that his harvests aren’t going well. Ikrom lacks the capital to be able to correctly prepare the land and thereby achieve a successful harvest so that he can sell his vegetables in the different markets. He is hoping for your generosity and is very thankful to all of you.

loans.name: Saing You's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Saing You T. is 45 years old and she is the village bank president of her group loan, which consists of fourteen members and is located in Preak Samroang village in Kandal province. Each member of this village loan will use it to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Saing You T. is a grocery seller who owns a general store. She decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to expand her business, and with the rest of the loan she wants to buy a new bicycle. Her husband, Mr. Sour Khoem, is a foreman in a kiln company where he earns a small salary to support his family. This couple has four children who are all students and who support their mother in her business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store and to buy a bicycle

loans.name: Sodikhuja

texts.en:
Since he was a boy, Sodikhuja has loved animals. He has learned to raise them well so that he can market them. Sodikhuja is married and has two kids to provide for. To support his family, he has to invest in his livestock business and, consequently, he's approached IMON International to apply for a loan that will allow him to purchase young cattle and feed for them. This will, in turn, increase his income from the milk, meat, horn, etc. that cattle provide.

loans.name: Ung

texts.en:
Ung N., 48, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She buys smoked fish for sale for a gross income of about USD 100 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning a gross income of USD 20 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

N. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase more smoked fish for resale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

loans.use: buy more smoked fish for resale

loans.name: Nasirullo

texts.en:
Nasirullo is 48 years old and lives with his wife and three children. This man has been a farmer for more than 5 years. Together with his family he grows diverse products such as cucumbers, onions, wheat, barley and other vegetables. What pleases him is sowing his diverse crops as it is profitable to invest in a variety of vegetables and sell his harvest monthly, according to market demand. But the most tedious part is having to clear his land and take care of his crops day after day. This is his first loan with IMON International and he is promising to repay the loan ion time, not letting down anyone. Nasirullo will invest the money in purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants.

loans.name: Moa's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Moa H. is a 38-year-old married woman and she is the leader of a group loan which consists of eight members, located in Champuh K’aek village in Kandal province. With their loans, the members will buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Moa H. is a grocery seller who can earn a small income to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more groceries to resell. Her husband, Mr. Nhor OE., is a construction worker, helping support his family with his small salary. This couple has two children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory while the younger one is 2 years old.

loans.name: Mrs. Kimly Nob Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eighteen people, who make up this village bank loan, live in Sampan village in Kandal province. Mrs. Kimly N. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. They will use their loan for different purposes. She is a government worker and aside from this, she is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow crops to sell to support her family. In her field, she has a problem because her field has infertile soil, but she does not have enough money to amend the soil. Thus, Mrs. Kimly N. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. She is widow who does not have a child.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Iyn

texts.en:
Iyn M. is from the village of Katutungan, Wao Lanao Del Sur. She is 28 years old. Iyn is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Iyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Iyn has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4,400 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Iyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Iyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. Iyn decided to request a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Iyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Miyansarkhon

texts.en:
Miyansarkhon, together with her partner, has a small business selling construction supplies in their store which has lately been expanded. Their store is filled with attractive, reasonably priced items that appeal to many customers who are looking to build something like an office, a house, etc. 

Miyansarkhon has been in business for about 4 years. She likes what she sells and has developed a stable enterprise. Currently she has requested a loan to help purchase a new supply of items to sell. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new supplies of items to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is married to a businessman. They have one child and the child is still young. She rents a two roomed house where she stays with five people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Betty takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include rent, feeding the family and medication. Betty owns a restaurant selling all types of food and receives at least 30 customers a day. Her customers are mainly her neighbors. She incurs transport costs to and from buying foodstuffs. Besides this food business, she also sells beer and soda plus other liquors.  Betty has been in this business for some years and her business challenges include seasonality and transportation.  Betty has been with MCDT for a few years servicing her third loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, charcoal and two crates of beer and soda. Sheis aspisring of seeing her business grow bigger and own a fully stocked restaurant.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs, like bananas, charcoal, beer and soda

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem S., 43, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She sells fish for an income of about USD 6 per day. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of USD 4 per day to help cover the family expenses.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more fish to expand the current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her fifth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more fish to expand the current business

loans.name: Sokeng's Group

texts.en: Mr. SokE. H. is 52 years old and was selected as the leader of this group loan by all six members. The group is located in Steung Chrov village in Kandal province.  The members will each use their portion of the loan for different types of businesses but all hope to increase their income to improve life for their families. Mr. SokE. H. earns a small income as a commune assistant, which he uses to support his family including his wife Mrs. Vanny On, who is a fish seller.  Mr. SokE. H. is requesting this loan to buy fish for his wife's business. This couple has four children.  Two are bakers and the other two are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fish for selling.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem S., age 49, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She is a teacher and farmer and is able to earn an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase chickens and pigs to raise. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy chickens and pigs to raise.

loans.name: Mahmadnaib

texts.en:
H. Mahmadnaib is 37 years old. He has been selling different kinds of paints and other construction materials in the market for the past 10 years, during which time he has acquired the knowledge and skills required to open his store. Since he started his store, his clientele has increased thanks to his good service. He is requesting a loan of 2000 USD, which he will use to buy merchandise to increase his assortment of items for sale. With your help Mahmadnaib will get ahead.

loans.use: To buy construction items for his store.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza B. is from the village of Eastern in Wao, Lanao Del Sur. She is 34 years old and married with 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Riza runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Riza has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Riza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Riza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. Riza is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Riza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support education of children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the product offering in her store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Sreypov's Group

texts.en: Srey Pov T. is from Preak Raing village in Kandal province. Srey Pov T. is a 28-year-old married woman and is the leader of this 4-member group loan. Each member of this village loan will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses. Srey Pov T. is a grocery seller and wants to buy more groceries to expnad her business, and also buy an ice box to support her business. Her husband, Mr. Sovannarith Tea, is a soldier and receives a small salary to support his family. This couple has a child who is 3 years old.

loans.use: To buy groceries for selling and an ice box.

loans.name: Pirnazar

texts.en:
Pirnazar J. is a hardworking father with responsibility of taking care of his wife and three children, who are the driving force for his work. Every day, early in the morning, Pirnazar leaves to take care of his farmland, which he irrigates and fertilizes so his crops will produce, and then when the harvest comes he can sell good quality products to sell for his income. His wife and children also help him with his business. One of this couple’s dreams is to educate their children with higher education so that one day they’ll become great people. They are asking for the current loan to buy seed, fertilizer and other supplies necessary for farming their land and increasing their crop production.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer, and other farming supplies.

loans.name: Mrs. Sdaung Chourng Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of nineteen people from Sampan village I. Kandal province. Mrs. Sdaung C. is the village bank president who was been selected by the other members, who will all use their portion of the loan for different purposes. She and her husband are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow crops to support their family. Now they face some problems because their field is on time to do farming, but they did not have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Sdaung C. decided to ask for a loan to buy corn seed, fertilizer, and fuel. She is the mother of three children,  two of whom are enrolled I. local public school, while the other is still too yO. for school.

loans.use: To buy corn seed, fertilizer, and fuel.

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en: Sourn S., age 30, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She sells second-hand clothes, earning an income of about USD 6 per day. Her husband produces wooden furniture, earning an income of USD 13 per day to help cover the family expenses.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more equipment to produce wooden furniture.  In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the education of her children.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy equipment to produce wooden furniture.

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
O. Dilorom is a 50-year-old married mother of 3 children who has been running her own business for more than a year now. She has a small salon where she sells and rents traditional wedding dresses. Traditionally families in Tajikistan are large, consequently there are lots of marriages and Dilorom has a lot of clients. The stability of her business allows her to make a considerable contribution to the family’s income. Today Dilorom requests 3000 USD for which will be used to purchase new wedding dresses. Dilorom would like to assure all deciding to support her that she will pay the loan in time and sincerely thanks you.

loans.use: To buy new wedding dresses for her shop.

loans.name: Beou

texts.en:
Beou C., 27, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its clay and ceramic products.

C. sells groceries at home for a gross income of about USD 20 per day. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning a gross income of USD 23 per day to help cover the family expenses.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a sugarcane squeezer to add to her grocery store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a sugarcane squeezer to add to her grocery store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more Garri (cassava flakes) to sell

loans.name: Srey Mom's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey Mom L. is a 26-year-old married woman and she has been selected by the members as the leader of this group loan, which consists of six members located in Lech Pram village in Kandal province. The member of this group will each use the loan to support a different purpose.

Mrs. Srey Mom L. is a grocery seller and also a rice wine maker. With these two businesses she is able earn a small income to support her family.

Mrs. Srey Mom now is requesting a loan to buy more groceries to resell and to buy rice to support her wine making. Her husband, Mr. Sokunthea Sakk, is a construction worker who receives a small salary to support his family. This couple has a child who is 3 years old.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell and more rice to support her wine making

loans.name: Bwamukama Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
K. Sophia is a vibrant woman with the firm courage of her convictions. The 26-year-old engaging mother of one had to dispense with and take exception to all the entrenched stereotypes associated with the fishmonger business in order to get established. She has a strong sense of self-esteem and this was her secret stock in trade.

At length, and to all appearances, Sophia has achieved some tides of success as her business as a fishmonger now brings her profits adding up to 100,000 shillings a month. Her business with her modest earnings is, in her own estimation, now standing in good stead.

Sophia principally sells dried and smoked fish. Season in, season out, she has made headway in a business flagged off its feet by her husband. Prior to bearing a hand in this business, she was a farmer. Her only child, as one of the testaments of her success, is now going to school.

With this loan coming her way, Sophia foresees her flood tide of success continuing as she says she will be able to buy more quality fish to sell. She also wants to increase the supplies of fresh fish to her stall.

loans.use: To make a downpayment to fish suppliers to increase the fresh-fish supplies to her business

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: Edith is married to a businessman who deals in spare parts. They have three children and all her children go to school. Edith takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a two-room house where she stays with seven people. She has been in this business for four years. Edith owns a retail shop in Katanga and sells all day-to-day items including sugar, salt, matchboxes and soap. She works seven days a week at her business premises and at her home.  Edith incurs transport costs to and from shopping in Kampala city and goes shopping twice a week. Besides this retail shop business, she also owns motorcycles for hire, which bring in additional income on a daily basis. She wants to use this loan of 300000/= to buy two bags of sugar, one box of soap, cartons of salt and one jerry can of cooking oil. Edith aspires to see her business grow bigger and own a wholesale shop. Her monthly expenses includes feeding the family, rent and school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap, salt and cooking oil

loans.name: Rahmatullo

texts.en: Z. Rahmatullo is 58 years old and has a successful business selling flour, rice and mineral fertilizer at the local market of Shahrituz region. He sells an assortment of different items of good quality. Because Rahmatullo buys his goods wholesale, his prices are cheaper than those of his competitors. Thus he has many customers who even make a purchase of his products straight from his house. Today Rahmatullo has great demand for his goods and that is why he wants to take an individual loan. He has requested a loan of 13,000 Somoni to add to his working capital to allow him to purchase more inventory. Rahmatullo is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices, and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. IMON International believes his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business. loans.use: To purchase flour and rice to increase his stock of goods

loans.name: That's Group

texts.en:
Four people located in Prey Totoeng village in Kandal province make up this group loan. Mrs. That P., 30 years old, is the leader of the group who has selected by all the members. Each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purpose.

Mrs. That P. is a pig breeder and her husband, Mr. Nget Peang, is a charcoal seller. With these two businesses they are able to earn a small income to support their family living.

Since her pig business is going well, Mrs. That P. wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets to raise. The rest of the loan she wants use to buy pig feed to support her pigs.

This couple has two children who are both too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and more piglets to raise

loans.name: Kon Tol

texts.en:
Mrs. Kon Tol B., born in 1983, lives in Kaoh Reah Leu village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who hires a small piece of land on which to grow crops to support her family.

In her crop field Mrs. Kon Tol B. has some problems because her field is far from the irrigation system. Thus, in order to improve her crop, she decided to ask for a loan to buy gasoline to pump water to support her papaya field.

Mrs. Kon Tol B.’s husband, Mr. Sok Oun, is a horse and cart driver who is able to earn some money to support his family living. They have two children who are too small to work or study. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy gasoline to pump water to irrigate her papaya field

loans.name: Alisher

texts.en:
A. Alisher is 27 years old and the father of two children. Alisher is a villager in Istaravshan in Northern Tajikistan. He and his wife are farmers who own farming land to cultivate vegetables. At the same time, Alisher raises cattle at his house. On their plantation, they now face an obstacle because they do not have enough money to buy seeds and fertilizer for planting. So, Alisher decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Alisher’s children are studying at school. He hopes he can continue to provide for them so they will be able to receive an adequate education.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Yoeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeun K. is a 36-year-old married woman and she is the leader of a group loan selected by nine members, located in Koh Chamroeun village in Kandal province. Each member of this group loan will use their share to support their different purposes. With the loans all the members also hope to increase income to improve their families' living standards. 

Mrs. Yoeun K. is a grocery seller who can earn a small income to support herself. Since this business is going well she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business activities. Mrs. Yoeun K. is a widow and does not have any children.

loans.use: to buy more groceries

loans.name: Islomdjon

texts.en:
For the past 8 years, Islomdjon has put much effort into his agricultural activities in the town of Shahristan in Northern Tajikistan. Despite the difficult economic situation, he has managed to support his family and provide them with necessary food and clothing. Islomdjon seeks loan support from IMON International to invest in his crops, later raise his harvest, and survive along with his family. With the part of the loan he will also purchase young cattle. With your help, Islomdjon will be able to get ahead.

loans.use: Purchasing young cattle and fertilizer

loans.name: Asror

texts.en:
I. Asror is a humble farmer. He is married and has two children. His job as a farmer is the only source of income for his family. He works on a plot of land of 0.8 hectares and he is awaiting harvest season at the moment. The main problem he is facing in farming is lack of capital to enable him to buy high quality seeds and also to buy fertilizer. Therefore Asror is applying for a loan from IMON International. He will use the loan money to buy high quality seed, fertilizer, and pesticide. 

Asror hopes to be able to improve the quality of his harvest by having all of those. With this his revenue will increase and he will be able to finance his children's education to higher level and also to meet his family's daily needs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and beads to sell

loans.name: Naimjon

texts.en:
Z. Naimjon has been a farmer for 11 years. He is married with three children. Through his many sacrifices he is characterized as a great worker who has helped maintain his household. Naimjon's family has passed through some very difficult economic times. IMON International has helped him with a credit that has allowed him to improve his situation through the purchase of and investment in fertilizer for his crops. Once again Naimjon asks for a loan to purchase fertilizers and other products to improve his crops. Your generosity can improve this family’s living.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha C. is a villager in Veal Thom village and she was born in 1952. She is a housewife and her husband is a government worker and aside from this, he is a fisherman who can earn only a little income. Her husband’s fishing business has a problem because he does not have enough fishing gear. Thus, Mrs. Sokha C. decided to ask for a loan to buy some fishing gear. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while another one is a policeman, and the third is attending local public school. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To buy some fishing gear

loans.name: Sros' Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sros T. is a 29-year-old married woman and she is the leader of a group loan selected by six members, located in Boueng Kroam village in Kandal province. Each member of this group loan will use their share to purchase supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Sros T. and her husband, Mr. Pin Poch are farmers who own a 1-hectare field to cultivate corn on. They do not have enough money to support their farm, so, Mrs. Sros T. decided to ask for a loan to buy corn seed to grow crops. Mrs. Sros T. is a mother of two children who both are too young to study or work.

loans.use: to buy corn seed

loans.name: Proloung

texts.en: Mr. Proloung Y., 35 years old, is a villager who lives in Popeal Kher IDL village in Kandal province. He is an iron welder and his wife, Mrs. Vanny Sorn, is a vegetable seller. With these two businesses, they can earn a small income to support their family. They now face a problem because their house needs to be repaired. Thus, Mr. Proloung Y. decided to ask for a loan to fix up his house. This couple has two children; one is attending in a local school while the younger one is 4 years old. Her husband is also in the picture.

loans.use: to fix up his house

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en: Teopista is married to a sugarcane seller in Nalukongo. They have five children and only one is in school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a one-room house where she stays with four people. She works with her husband in sugarcane and she also sells timber. She incurs transport costs to and from buying sugarcane from the villages. She uses public transport and goes shopping once a week. Teopista's business challenges include transportation of sugarcane from the villages to her stall, defaulters and the rainy season, which makes roads impassable. She sells at both retail and wholesale. Teopista joined MCDT because she wanted to increase her capital base and because MCDT was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more sugarcane and invest partly in timber. She aspires to see her business grow big and start supplying different customers.

loans.use: To buy more sugarcane and timber

loans.name: Moa

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinourn Yorn is 38 years old and is a villager who lives in Peam Sala village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sinourn Yorn and her husband, Mr. Mao Toem, are farmers who own 1-hectare field to cultivate rice on to earn a living. Mrs. Sinourn Yorn decided to ask for a loan to pay for plowing laborer; with the rest of the loan she wants to fix up her house. 

Aside from farming, Mr. Mao Toem is a fisherman who can earn just a small income to support his family. This couple has five children; one is laborer and three are attending local school while the youngest one is 3 years old. Her husband is also in the picture.

loans.use: to pay for plowing laborer and to fix up her house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more dried pepper to sell

loans.name: Sambath
